We now state some preliminary lemmas and definitions that are recurrently used in this manuscript.

Definition 1 (Minimal modulus of continuity[24])

Let h:𝒳→ℝ:ℎ→𝒳ℝh:\mathcal{X}\to\mathbb{R}italic_h : caligraphic_X → blackboard_R be a continuous function over a bounded set 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X. The minimal modulus of continuity of hℎhitalic_h on 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X is defined as

ωh(γ):=sup{|h(x)−h(y)|:x,y∈𝒳,∥x−y∥∞≤γ}.\omega_{h}(\gamma):=\mathrm{sup}\Big{\{}|h(x)-h(y)|:x,y\in\mathcal{X},\lVert x% -y\rVert_{\infty}\leq\gamma\Big{\}}.italic_ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_γ ) := roman_sup { | italic_h ( italic_x ) - italic_h ( italic_y ) | : italic_x , italic_y ∈ caligraphic_X , ∥ italic_x - italic_y ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_γ } .
Definition 2 (Persistently exciting input [25])

The signal u∈ℝn𝑢superscriptℝ𝑛u\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_u ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is said to be persistently exciting of order n𝑛nitalic_n if there exists a time span S>0𝑆0S>0italic_S > 0 such that for all k>0𝑘0k>0italic_k > 0, the matrix formed by the columns uk+i∈ℝnsuperscript𝑢𝑘𝑖superscriptℝ𝑛u^{k+i}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for i∈{0,1,…⁢S}𝑖01…𝑆i\in\{0,1,\ldots S\}italic_i ∈ { 0 , 1 , … italic_S } has full rank, i.e. Rank⁢[uk⁢uk+1⁢…⁢uk+S]=nRankdelimited-[]superscript𝑢𝑘superscript𝑢𝑘1…superscript𝑢𝑘𝑆𝑛\mathrm{Rank}[u^{k}\ u^{k+1}\ \ldots\ u^{k+S}]=nroman_Rank [ italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT … italic_u start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + italic_S end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] = italic_n.

Definition 3 (Global β𝛽\betaitalic_β-smoothness [26])

A continuously differentiable map Φ:ℝn→ℝ:Φ→superscriptℝ𝑛ℝ\Phi:\mathbb{R}^{n}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}roman_Φ : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R is globally β𝛽\betaitalic_β-smooth if its gradient ∇Φ∇Φ\nabla\Phi∇ roman_Φ is globally β𝛽\betaitalic_β-Lipschitz.

Lemma 1 (Properties of β𝛽\betaitalic_β-smooth functions [26])

Given a globally β𝛽\betaitalic_β-smooth map Φ:ℝn→ℝ:Φ→superscriptℝ𝑛ℝ\Phi:\mathbb{R}^{n}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}roman_Φ : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R, then Φ⁢(x1)−Φ⁢(x2)−∇Φ⊤⁢(x2)⁢(x1−x2)≤12⁢β⁢∥x1−x2∥2Φsubscript𝑥1Φsubscript𝑥2∇superscriptΦtopsubscript𝑥2subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥212𝛽superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥22\Phi(x_{1})-\Phi(x_{2})-\nabla\Phi^{\top}(x_{2})(x_{1}-x_{2})\leq\frac{1}{2}% \beta\lVert x_{1}-x_{2}\rVert^{2}roman_Φ ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_Φ ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - ∇ roman_Φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_β ∥ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Further, if ΦΦ\Phiroman_Φ is twice continuously-differentiable, then ∥∇2Φ∥≤βdelimited-∥∥superscript∇2Φ𝛽\lVert\nabla^{2}\Phi\rVert\leq\beta∥ ∇ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Φ ∥ ≤ italic_β.

2 Problem setup

2.1 Social Network Modelling

We consider a recommender system for a social network consisting of n𝑛nitalic_n users, indexed by i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] that makes sequential, personalized recommendations. User opinions are collected into a vector x∈[−1,1]n𝑥superscript11𝑛x\in[-1,1]^{n}italic_x ∈ [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, with xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ], denoting the opinion of the i𝑖iitalic_i-th user. The users’ opinions evolve as

xk+1=f⁢(xk,pk,d),superscript𝑥𝑘1𝑓superscript𝑥𝑘superscript𝑝𝑘𝑑x^{k+1}=f(x^{k},p^{k},d),italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_f ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d ) , (1)

where p∈[−1, 1]n𝑝superscript11𝑛p\in[-1,\ 1]^{n}italic_p ∈ [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT refers to the positions that the recommended article takes on, whose i𝑖iitalic_i-th entry is the position provided to the i𝑖iitalic_i-th user, d∈[−1, 1]n𝑑superscript11𝑛d\in[-1,\ 1]^{n}italic_d ∈ [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT represents an external influence to the platform, e.g., television, newspapers or a personal bias, and f:([−1, 1]n)3→[−1, 1]n:𝑓→superscriptsuperscript11𝑛3superscript11𝑛f:([-1,\ 1]^{n})^{3}\to[-1,\ 1]^{n}italic_f : ( [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT encodes the influence of interactions among users. We assume there is a single topic of discussion or issue, on the platform. For the sake of illustration, if the issue is polarizing, then, a recommendation with position p=+1𝑝1p=+1italic_p = + 1 (−11-1- 1) can be interpreted as news strongly in support of (against) the issue.

The following assumption ensures that the dynamics (1) are well-posed and admit a steady-state mapping.

Assumption 1 (Well-posedness)

The following hold:

  1. (i)

    The dynamics (1) are forward invariant in [−1, 1]nsuperscript11𝑛[-1,\ 1]^{n}[ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, i.e.,

    x0,p0,d0∈[−1, 1]n⇒xk∈[−1, 1]n,∀k∈ℕ0.formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑥0superscript𝑝0superscript𝑑0superscript11𝑛⇒superscript𝑥𝑘superscript11𝑛for-all𝑘subscriptℕ0x^{0},p^{0},d^{0}\in[-1,\ 1]^{n}\,\Rightarrow\,x^{k}\in[-1,\ 1]^{n},\;\forall k% \in\mathbb{N}_{0}.italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⇒ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , ∀ italic_k ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .
  2. (ii)

    The dynamics (1) are uniformly exponentially stable with constant p,d𝑝𝑑p,ditalic_p , italic_d, and admit a unique steady-state map h:([−1, 1]n)2→[−1, 1]n:ℎ→superscriptsuperscript11𝑛2superscript11𝑛h:\big{(}[-1,\ 1]^{n}\big{)}^{2}\rightarrow[-1,\ 1]^{n}italic_h : ( [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfying

    h⁢(p,d)=f⁢(h⁢(p,d),p,d),∀p,d∈[−1, 1]n.formulae-sequenceℎ𝑝𝑑𝑓ℎ𝑝𝑑𝑝𝑑for-all𝑝𝑑superscript11𝑛h(p,d)=f(h(p,d),p,d),\quad\forall p,d\in[-1,\ 1]^{n}.italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) = italic_f ( italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) , italic_p , italic_d ) , ∀ italic_p , italic_d ∈ [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .
  3. (iii)

    The map h⁢(p,d)ℎ𝑝𝑑h(p,d)italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) is continuously-differentiable and L−limit-from𝐿L-italic_L -Lipschitz [26] with respect to p𝑝pitalic_p. □□\square□

This assumption can be easily adopted for a wide array of renowned opinion dynamics models, such as De-Groot model [17], FJ model [16], and polar opinion dynamics model [18], among others, for which the influence of a recommender system can be, in principle, included. For an extensive list of such models, we refer the reader to the survey [27]. Traditionally, in fact, these models consider social interactions and prejudice as the only driving forces behind opinion formation. Nonetheless, recommendations on contentious topics provably influence user opinions [9], underscoring the need to include their influence in the opinion dynamics. Next, we illustrate an example of how the FJ model, one of the most widely used opinion dynamics models across different communities [28, 29, 30, 31, 32, 9, 10], can be extended to capture the effects of the recommender on networked users.

Example 1 (Extended Friedkin–Johnsen model)

The opinions evolve according to

xk+1=(In−Γp−Γd)⁢A⁢xk+Γp⁢pk+Γd⁢d,superscript𝑥𝑘1subscript𝐼𝑛subscriptΓ𝑝subscriptΓ𝑑𝐴superscript𝑥𝑘subscriptΓ𝑝superscript𝑝𝑘subscriptΓ𝑑𝑑x^{k+1}=(I_{n}-\Gamma_{p}-\Gamma_{d})Ax^{k}+\Gamma_{p}p^{k}+\Gamma_{d}d,italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - roman_Γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - roman_Γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_A italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d , (2)

where Γd,ΓpsubscriptΓ𝑑subscriptΓ𝑝\Gamma_{d},\Gamma_{p}roman_Γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are positive diagonal matrices such that Γp+Γd⪯Inprecedes-or-equalssubscriptΓ𝑝subscriptΓ𝑑subscript𝐼𝑛\Gamma_{p}+\Gamma_{d}\preceq I_{n}roman_Γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + roman_Γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⪯ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, describing the impact of d𝑑ditalic_d and p𝑝pitalic_p over the opinions, and A𝐴Aitalic_A is a row-stochastic adjacency matrix encoding the social interconnections of the users. The dynamics (2) are forward-invariant in [−1,1]nsuperscript11𝑛[-1,1]^{n}[ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, since the opinions are a convex combination of x,p,d∈[−1,1]n𝑥𝑝𝑑superscript11𝑛x,p,d\in[-1,1]^{n}italic_x , italic_p , italic_d ∈ [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Further, for a constant position provided by the recommender system, the steady-state mapping is single-valued, affine (hence, continuously differentiable), and reads as

h⁢(p,d)=(In−(In−Γp−Γd)⁢A)−1⁢(Γp⁢p+Γd⁢d).ℎ𝑝𝑑superscriptsubscript𝐼𝑛subscript𝐼𝑛subscriptΓ𝑝subscriptΓ𝑑𝐴1subscriptΓ𝑝𝑝subscriptΓ𝑑𝑑h(p,d)=(I_{n}-(I_{n}-\Gamma_{p}-\Gamma_{d})A)^{-1}(\Gamma_{p}p+\Gamma_{d}d).italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) = ( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - roman_Γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - roman_Γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_A ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_Γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p + roman_Γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d ) .

Note that by taking Γp=OnsubscriptΓ𝑝subscript𝑂𝑛\Gamma_{p}=O_{n}roman_Γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_O start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and d=x0𝑑superscript𝑥0d=x^{0}italic_d = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT to be an initial bias, the dynamics (2) reduce to the standard FJ model [16]. △△\triangle△

Engagement of the users over the platform is measured in terms of CTR, measured as number of clicks over number of provided news articles. As common practice in the context of implicit feedback recommender systems [33], for a generic user i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] holding an opinion xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we model the probability of i𝑖iitalic_i clicking on a recommendation with position pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as a random variable cisubscript𝑐𝑖c_{i}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT sampled from a Bernoulli distribution with unknown argument gi⁢(pi,xi)subscript𝑔𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖g_{i}(p_{i},x_{i})italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), i.e. ci∼ℬ⁢(gi⁢(pi,xi))similar-tosubscript𝑐𝑖ℬsubscript𝑔𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖c_{i}\sim\mathcal{B}(g_{i}(p_{i},x_{i}))italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ caligraphic_B ( italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ). The argument gi⁢(pi,xi)subscript𝑔𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖g_{i}(p_{i},x_{i})italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) represents the clicking behaviour of user i𝑖iitalic_i and depends on the user’s opinion xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as well as the position of the recommendation pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We will work under the following regularity assumptions on the clicking behaviour:

Assumption 2 (Clicking behaviour)

The clicking behaviour g⁢(p,x):[−1,1]n×[−1,1]n→[0,1]n:𝑔𝑝𝑥→superscript11𝑛superscript11𝑛superscript01𝑛g(p,x):[-1,1]^{n}\times[-1,1]^{n}\to[0,1]^{n}italic_g ( italic_p , italic_x ) : [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT × [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is Mxsubscript𝑀𝑥M_{x}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - Lipschitz with respect to x𝑥xitalic_x, and Lpsubscript𝐿𝑝L_{p}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT- and Lxsubscript𝐿𝑥L_{x}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-smooth with respect to p𝑝pitalic_p and x𝑥xitalic_x, respectively. □□\square□

Next, we provide an example of a clicking behaviour.

Example 2 (Extremity confirmation bias [9])

A user i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i~{}\in~{}[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ], holding opinion xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, affected by extremity confirmation bias clicks on a recommendation pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with probability

ci∼ℬ⁢(12+12⁢xi⁢pi),similar-tosubscript𝑐𝑖ℬ1212subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖c_{i}\sim\mathcal{B}\left(\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{2}x_{i}p_{i}\right),italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ caligraphic_B ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ,

where the clicking behaviour gi⁢(pi,xi)=12+12⁢xi⁢pisubscript𝑔𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖1212subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖g_{i}(p_{i},x_{i})=\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{2}x_{i}p_{i}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT models confirmation bias towards extreme recommendations. In fact, for an opinion xi≈±1subscript𝑥𝑖plus-or-minus1x_{i}\approx\pm 1italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≈ ± 1 and a position pi≈±1subscript𝑝𝑖plus-or-minus1p_{i}\approx\pm 1italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≈ ± 1 (∓1minus-or-plus1\mp 1∓ 1), the probability of clicking is almost 1111 (00). The click event becomes random as the user position approaches the neutral stance pi≈0subscript𝑝𝑖0p_{i}\approx 0italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≈ 0, highlighting diminished engagement for less polarized content or when recommendations directly counter the user’s stance on the issue. △△\triangle△

2.2 Problem formulation

The goal of the recommender system is to provide recommendations that optimize a specific metric, denoted as φ⁢(p,x)𝜑𝑝𝑥\varphi(p,x)italic_φ ( italic_p , italic_x ). Typical choices in the literature include maximizing CTR [9, 10], opinion control [34], and polarization mitigation [35]. Deviating from traditional recommender systems, we consider a multi-objective cost function combining engagement maximization and polarization mitigation, given by

φ⁢(p,x)=φctr⁢(p,x)+γ⁢φpol⁢(x),𝜑𝑝𝑥superscript𝜑ctr𝑝𝑥𝛾superscript𝜑pol𝑥\varphi(p,x)=\varphi^{\text{ctr}}(p,x)+\gamma\,\varphi^{\text{pol}}(x),italic_φ ( italic_p , italic_x ) = italic_φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p , italic_x ) + italic_γ italic_φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT pol end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) , (3)

where γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ is a non-negative trade-off parameter. The engagement-related term in (3) is the CTR, formalized as

φctr⁢(p,x)=−∑i∈[n]𝔼ci∼𝔹⁢(gi⁢(xi,pi))⁢[ci],superscript𝜑ctr𝑝𝑥subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝑐𝑖𝔹subscript𝑔𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖delimited-[]subscript𝑐𝑖\varphi^{\text{ctr}}(p,x)=-\sum_{i\in[n]}\mathbb{E}_{c_{i}\sim\mathbb{B}(g_{i}% (x_{i},p_{i}))}[\,c_{i}\,],italic_φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p , italic_x ) = - ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ blackboard_B ( italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] ,

where 𝔼ci∼𝔹⁢(gi⁢(xi,pi))⁢[ci]subscript𝔼similar-tosubscript𝑐𝑖𝔹subscript𝑔𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖delimited-[]subscript𝑐𝑖\mathbb{E}_{c_{i}\sim\mathbb{B}(g_{i}(x_{i},p_{i}))}[\,c_{i}\,]blackboard_E start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ blackboard_B ( italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] is the expectation of user i𝑖iitalic_i’s clicking, given their opinion xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and a recommendation with position pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The second term in (3), φpolsuperscript𝜑pol\varphi^{\rm pol}italic_φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_pol end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, is a smooth and Lipschitz function that measures opinion polarization. For our algorithm we consider it to be φpol⁢(x):=∑i∈[n]si⁢(x)assignsuperscript𝜑pol𝑥subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝑠𝑖𝑥\varphi^{\text{pol}}(x):=\sum_{i\in[n]}s_{i}(x)italic_φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT pol end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) := ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ), where sisubscript𝑠𝑖s_{i}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT penalizes deviations from the moderate (zero) opinions:

si⁢(xi)={(xi−ϵ1)2xi<ϵ10ϵ1≤xi≤ϵ2(ϵ2−xi)2xi>ϵ2subscript𝑠𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖casessuperscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖subscriptitalic-ϵ12subscript𝑥𝑖subscriptitalic-ϵ10subscriptitalic-ϵ1subscript𝑥𝑖subscriptitalic-ϵ2superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ2subscript𝑥𝑖2subscript𝑥𝑖subscriptitalic-ϵ2\displaystyle s_{i}(x_{i})=\begin{cases}(x_{i}-\epsilon_{1})^{2}&x_{i}<% \epsilon_{1}\\ 0&\epsilon_{1}\leq x_{i}\leq\epsilon_{2}\\ (\epsilon_{2}-x_{i})^{2}&x_{i}>\epsilon_{2}\end{cases}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = { start_ROW start_CELL ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL ( italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW (4)

Therein, the parameters ϵ1≤ϵ2subscriptitalic-ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ2\epsilon_{1}\leq\epsilon_{2}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are used to control the degree of penalty towards extreme opinions. Specifically, a smaller positive (negative) choice for ϵ2subscriptitalic-ϵ2\epsilon_{2}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ1\epsilon_{1}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) indicates a higher penalty on extreme positive (negative) opinions. According to [36], the metric in (4) falls in the class of polarization spread, indicating how extreme the opinions are. Note that, for ϵ1=ϵ2=0subscriptitalic-ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ20\epsilon_{1}=\epsilon_{2}=0italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, the term (4) reduces to φpol⁢(x)=∥x∥2superscript𝜑pol𝑥superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑥2\varphi^{\text{pol}}(x)=\lVert x\rVert^{2}italic_φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT pol end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = ∥ italic_x ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, another classic measure for opinion polarization [29].

The recommender system aims at finding the recommendation that drives the user population with dynamics (1) to a steady-state minimizing the multi-objective cost (3):

minimizep,x𝑝𝑥minimize\displaystyle\underset{p,\,x}{\mathrm{minimize}}start_UNDERACCENT italic_p , italic_x end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_minimize end_ARG φ⁢(p,x)𝜑𝑝𝑥\displaystyle\quad\varphi(p,x)italic_φ ( italic_p , italic_x ) (5a)
s.t. x=h⁢(p,d)𝑥ℎ𝑝𝑑\displaystyle\quad x=h(p,d)italic_x = italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) (5b)
p∈[−1,1]n𝑝superscript11𝑛\displaystyle\quad p\in[-1,1]^{n}italic_p ∈ [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (5c)

This problem is uncertain and potentially non-convex, since the analytical form of the clicking behaviour is unknown and likely complex. Likewise, the opinion dynamics (1) are unknown. If the opinion dynamics in (1) and the clicking behavior gisubscript𝑔𝑖g_{i}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT were known, and an accurate prediction of external influences d𝑑ditalic_d were available, then one could aim to solve (5) offline. However, in practice, none of these information is readily available, and the recommender system can provide personalized positions solely relying on clicks {cik}superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑖𝑘\{c_{i}^{k}\}{ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }.

Remark 1

Equation (5b) reflects the assumption that users’ opinions reach steady-state before the recommender system takes action. This approach is in line with most of the existing works on recommender systems that incorporates preference dynamics [10, 9, 37, 6, 38], where recommendation decisions are made based on the steady-state behavior of the users’ preferences under the model.

Our feedback control problem is formally stated as follows:

Problem 1

Design a feedback controller p⁢(c)𝑝𝑐p(c)italic_p ( italic_c ) so that (1) converges to a solution (p∗,x∗)superscript𝑝superscript𝑥(p^{*},x^{*})( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) of the optimization problem (5), assuming that only clicks ciksuperscriptsubscript𝑐𝑖𝑘c_{i}^{k}italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are available. The clicking behaviours gi⁢(pi,xi)subscript𝑔𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖g_{i}(p_{i},x_{i})italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), steady-state map h⁢(p,d)ℎ𝑝𝑑h(p,d)italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ), the opinion dynamics (1), external influence d𝑑ditalic_d are unknown, and the real-time opinions x𝑥xitalic_x are not measurable.

3 Recommender system design

We approach Problem 1 by designing a dynamic feedback controller inspired by the projected-gradient descent algorithm in [39, Section 3A]. The resulting recommender system dynamically generates recommendations as

pk+1=Π[−1,1]n⁢[pk−η⁢Φ⁢(pk,xk+1)],∀k∈ℕformulae-sequencesuperscript𝑝𝑘1subscriptΠsuperscript11𝑛delimited-[]superscript𝑝𝑘𝜂Φsuperscript𝑝𝑘superscript𝑥𝑘1for-all𝑘ℕp^{k+1}=\Pi_{[-1,1]^{n}}\big{[}p^{k}-\eta\,\Phi(p^{k},x^{k+1})\big{]},\quad% \forall k\in\mathbb{N}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_η roman_Φ ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ] , ∀ italic_k ∈ blackboard_N (6)

where η𝜂\etaitalic_η is a tunable controller gain, and

Φ⁢(p,x):=∇pφ⁢(p,x)+∇ph⁢(p,d)⊤⁢∇xφ⁢(p,x)assignΦ𝑝𝑥subscript∇𝑝𝜑𝑝𝑥subscript∇𝑝ℎsuperscript𝑝𝑑topsubscript∇𝑥𝜑𝑝𝑥\displaystyle\Phi(p,x):=\nabla_{p}\varphi(p,x)+\nabla_{p}h(p,d)^{\top}\nabla_{% x}\varphi(p,x)roman_Φ ( italic_p , italic_x ) := ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ ( italic_p , italic_x ) + ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ ( italic_p , italic_x ) (7)

represents the gradient obtained by applying the chain-rule of differentiation to the cost φ⁢(p,x)𝜑𝑝𝑥\varphi(p,x)italic_φ ( italic_p , italic_x ) in (5), with opinions at steady state, i.e., x=h⁢(p,d)𝑥ℎ𝑝𝑑x=h(p,d)italic_x = italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ). In practice, evaluating the gradient (7) at each sampling instant k𝑘kitalic_k requires access to:

  1. (i)

    Real-time users’ opinions xksuperscript𝑥𝑘x^{k}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT;

  2. (ii)

    Sensitivity mapping ∇ph⁢(p,d)subscript∇𝑝ℎ𝑝𝑑\nabla_{p}h(p,d)∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ); and

  3. (iii)

    Gradients ∇pφ⁢(p,x)subscript∇𝑝𝜑𝑝𝑥\nabla_{p}\varphi(p,x)∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ ( italic_p , italic_x ) and ∇xφ⁢(p,x)subscript∇𝑥𝜑𝑝𝑥\nabla_{x}\varphi(p,x)∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ ( italic_p , italic_x ).

None of the above information is readily available, making a direct implementation of the recommender design (6) impractical. In fact, the users’ opinion are not accessible in practice, their dynamics are generally unknown (and so are their sensitivities), and the gradients ∇pφsubscript∇𝑝𝜑\nabla_{p}\varphi∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ, ∇xφsubscript∇𝑥𝜑\nabla_{x}\varphi∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ depend on the users’ clicking behaviour g⁢(p,x)𝑔𝑝𝑥g(p,x)italic_g ( italic_p , italic_x ), which is also unknown. Instead, we have access only to the users’ clicks {ck}superscript𝑐𝑘\{c^{k}\}{ italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } from which we compute their CTRs yik:=∑t=k−Tkcit/(T+1),∀k≥Tformulae-sequenceassignsuperscriptsubscript𝑦𝑖𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑘𝑇𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑐𝑖𝑡𝑇1for-all𝑘𝑇y_{i}^{k}:=\sum_{t=k-T}^{k}c_{i}^{t}/(T+1),\forall\ k\geq Titalic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = italic_k - italic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / ( italic_T + 1 ) , ∀ italic_k ≥ italic_T, for some time window T𝑇Titalic_T. This can be regarded as an approximation of the expectation of a click, i.e., 𝔼⁢[ℬ⁢(g⁢(p,x))]=g⁢(p,x)𝔼delimited-[]ℬ𝑔𝑝𝑥𝑔𝑝𝑥\mathbb{E}\big{[}\mathcal{B}(g(p,x))\big{]}=g(p,x)blackboard_E [ caligraphic_B ( italic_g ( italic_p , italic_x ) ) ] = italic_g ( italic_p , italic_x ).

To cope with these challenges, we augment the controller (6) with three auxiliary blocks associated with users’ opinions, sensitivity, and clicking behaviour estimates in real-time. Specifically, we structure the design on three levels:

  1. (i)

    Estimation of real-time opinions and users’ clicking behaviour via supervised learning;

  2. (ii)

    Online sensitivity learning via Kalman filtering; and

  3. (iii)

    Gradient estimation via a forward difference method.

The resulting control architecture is illustrated in Fig. 2 and summarized in Algorithm 1. In the following three sections, we describe each level.

3.1 Level I: Opinions & Clicking Behaviour Estimation

The opinions and clicking behaviours are estimated using an Artificial Neural Network (ANN).

We estimate the opinions by relying on implicit feedback from the users, i.e., the CTR y≈𝔼⁢[ℬ⁢(g⁢(p,x))]𝑦𝔼delimited-[]ℬ𝑔𝑝𝑥y\approx\mathbb{E}\big{[}\mathcal{B}(g(p,x))\big{]}italic_y ≈ blackboard_E [ caligraphic_B ( italic_g ( italic_p , italic_x ) ) ] of the users on recommendations with position p𝑝pitalic_p. Thus, we seek a map to extract the opinions from the clicks and the positions, x=β⁢(y,p)𝑥𝛽𝑦𝑝x=\beta(y,p)italic_x = italic_β ( italic_y , italic_p ). To bound the resulting opinions and clicking behaviour estimation error from the ANN, we work under the following regularity assumptions [21, 40].

Assumption 3 (Opinion & Clicking behaviour maps)

We assume that

  1. i)

    There exists a continuous map β:[0,1]n×[−1,1]n→[−1,1]n:𝛽→superscript01𝑛superscript11𝑛superscript11𝑛\beta:[0,1]^{n}\times[-1,1]^{n}\to[-1,1]^{n}italic_β : [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT × [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is such that β⁢(y,p)=x+θ⁢(x)𝛽𝑦𝑝𝑥𝜃𝑥\beta(y,p)=x+\theta(x)italic_β ( italic_y , italic_p ) = italic_x + italic_θ ( italic_x ) with ∥θ⁢(x)∥≤θxdelimited-∥∥𝜃𝑥subscript𝜃𝑥\lVert\theta(x)\rVert\leq\theta_{x}∥ italic_θ ( italic_x ) ∥ ≤ italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for all x∈𝒳⊆[−1,1]n𝑥𝒳superscript11𝑛x\in\mathcal{X}\subseteq[-1,1]^{n}italic_x ∈ caligraphic_X ⊆ [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and θx<∞subscript𝜃𝑥\theta_{x}<\inftyitalic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < ∞; moreover, the image β⁢(𝒴,𝒫)𝛽𝒴𝒫\beta(\mathcal{Y},\mathcal{P})italic_β ( caligraphic_Y , caligraphic_P ) is compact for any 𝒴⊆[0,1]n,𝒫⊆[−1,1]nformulae-sequence𝒴superscript01𝑛𝒫superscript11𝑛\mathcal{Y}\subseteq[0,1]^{n},\mathcal{P}\subseteq[-1,1]^{n}caligraphic_Y ⊆ [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_P ⊆ [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

  2. ii)

    There exists a constant αy<∞subscript𝛼𝑦\alpha_{y}<\inftyitalic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < ∞ such that the composite function takes the form g⁢(p,β⁢(y,p))=y+∇xg⁢(p,x)⊤⁢θ⁢(x)+α⁢(y)𝑔𝑝𝛽𝑦𝑝𝑦subscript∇𝑥𝑔superscript𝑝𝑥top𝜃𝑥𝛼𝑦g(p,\beta(y,p))=y+\nabla_{x}g(p,x)^{\top}\theta(x)+\alpha(y)italic_g ( italic_p , italic_β ( italic_y , italic_p ) ) = italic_y + ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g ( italic_p , italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_θ ( italic_x ) + italic_α ( italic_y ), with ∥α⁢(y)∥≤αydelimited-∥∥𝛼𝑦subscript𝛼𝑦\lVert\alpha(y)\rVert\leq\alpha_{y}∥ italic_α ( italic_y ) ∥ ≤ italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for all y∈𝒴𝑦𝒴y\in\mathcal{Y}italic_y ∈ caligraphic_Y. □□\square□

Assumption 3 i) guarantees the map β⁢(y,p)𝛽𝑦𝑝\beta(y,p)italic_β ( italic_y , italic_p ) to provide an estimate on users’ opinions upper bounded by θxsubscript𝜃𝑥\theta_{x}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Similarly, Assumption 3 ii), guarantees the (opinion) map β⁢(y,p)𝛽𝑦𝑝\beta(y,p)italic_β ( italic_y , italic_p ) to (implicitly) provide an estimate on clicking behavior upper bounded by Mx⁢θx+αysubscript𝑀𝑥subscript𝜃𝑥subscript𝛼𝑦M_{x}\theta_{x}+\alpha_{y}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with Mxsubscript𝑀𝑥M_{x}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT resulting from Assumption 2. We will qualitatively describe how these upper bound errors can be tightened in Section 3.4.

In the remainder of this section, we denote by 𝒳p,𝒳x∈[−1,1]n×m,𝒳y∈[0,1]n×mformulae-sequencesubscript𝒳𝑝subscript𝒳𝑥superscript11𝑛𝑚subscript𝒳𝑦superscript01𝑛𝑚\mathcal{X}_{p},\mathcal{X}_{x}\in[-1,1]^{n\times m},\mathcal{X}_{y}\in[0,1]^{% n\times m}caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n × italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n × italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT the data sets of the positions, steady-state opinions, and the CTR used for training of the ANN. The process to acquire the training data is explained in detail in Appendix 5.1.

3.1.1 Opinion Estimation

Here, we describe the training process to estimate β𝛽{\beta}italic_β in Assumption 3 using an ANN.

For each user i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ], the input and output training sets are

[𝒳p𝒳y,i]∈{[−1,1]n×m[0,1]1×m},𝒳x,i∈[−1,1]1×m,formulae-sequencematrixsubscript𝒳𝑝subscript𝒳𝑦𝑖matrixsuperscript11𝑛𝑚superscript011𝑚subscript𝒳𝑥𝑖superscript111𝑚\begin{bmatrix}\mathcal{X}_{p}\\ \mathcal{X}_{y,i}\end{bmatrix}\in\begin{Bmatrix}[-1,1]^{n\times m}\\ [0,1]^{1\times m}\end{Bmatrix},\mathcal{X}_{x,i}\in[-1,1]^{1\times m},[ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] ∈ { start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n × italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 × italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG } , caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 × italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

respectively. Given that users interact with each other, the recommendations to users connected to user i𝑖iitalic_i will indirectly influence user i𝑖iitalic_i’s opinion xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. However, xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is not directly affected by the CTR of other users. To model this, we design the input layer with n+1𝑛1n+1italic_n + 1 neurons for each user: n𝑛nitalic_n neurons associated with p𝑝pitalic_p and one neuron associated with yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The output layer comprises a single neuron to represent xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Additionally, we incorporate an intermediate layer with n+2𝑛2n+2italic_n + 2 neurons. The intermediate layer employs a hyperbolic tangent activation function tanh⁡(x):ℝ→[−1,1]:𝑥→ℝ11\tanh(x):\mathbb{R}\rightarrow[-1,1]roman_tanh ( italic_x ) : blackboard_R → [ - 1 , 1 ], while the output layer uses an identity activation function.

Next, we provide an upper bound for the opinion estimation error ex:=h⁢(p,d)−β^⁢(y,p)assignsubscript𝑒𝑥ℎ𝑝𝑑^𝛽𝑦𝑝e_{x}:=h(p,d)-\hat{\beta}(y,p)italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) - over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG ( italic_y , italic_p ), where β^^𝛽\hat{\beta}over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG is the opinion estimate map learned by the neural network.

Lemma 2 (Opinion estimation error)

Under Assumption 3, the opinion estimation error is upper bounded as ∥ex∥≤ϵxdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑒𝑥subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑥\lVert e_{x}\rVert\leq\epsilon_{x}∥ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ≤ italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with

ϵx:=n[\displaystyle\epsilon_{x}:=\sqrt{n}\Big{[}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := square-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG [ 3⁢supy∈𝒳y,p∈𝒳p⁢∥β⁢(y,p)−β^⁢(y,p)∥∞+2⁢supi∈[n]⁢ωβi⁢(γx)+3formulae-sequence𝑦subscript𝒳𝑦𝑝subscript𝒳𝑝supsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝛽𝑦𝑝^𝛽𝑦𝑝limit-from2𝑖delimited-[]𝑛supsubscript𝜔subscript𝛽𝑖subscript𝛾𝑥\displaystyle 3\underset{y\in\mathcal{X}_{y},p\in\mathcal{X}_{p}}{\mathrm{sup}% }\lVert\beta(y,p)-\hat{\beta}(y,p)\rVert_{\infty}+2\underset{i\in[n]}{\mathrm{% sup}}\omega_{\beta_{i}}(\gamma_{x})+3 start_UNDERACCENT italic_y ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_sup end_ARG ∥ italic_β ( italic_y , italic_p ) - over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG ( italic_y , italic_p ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 start_UNDERACCENT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_sup end_ARG italic_ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) +
γxsupi∈[n]|v0,i|]+θx,\displaystyle\gamma_{x}\underset{i\in[n]}{\mathrm{sup}}|v_{0,i}|\Big{]}+\theta% _{x},italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_UNDERACCENT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_sup end_ARG | italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ] + italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (8)

where supy∈𝒳y,p∈𝒳p⁢∥β⁢(y,p)−β^⁢(y,p)∥∞formulae-sequence𝑦subscript𝒳𝑦𝑝subscript𝒳𝑝supsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝛽𝑦𝑝^𝛽𝑦𝑝\underset{y\in\mathcal{X}_{y},p\in\mathcal{X}_{p}}{\mathrm{sup}}\lVert\beta(y,% p)-\hat{\beta}(y,p)\rVert_{\infty}start_UNDERACCENT italic_y ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_sup end_ARG ∥ italic_β ( italic_y , italic_p ) - over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG ( italic_y , italic_p ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT represents the maximum opinion estimation error during training of the ANN, ωβi⁢(γx)subscript𝜔subscript𝛽𝑖subscript𝛾𝑥\omega_{\beta_{i}}(\gamma_{x})italic_ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is the minimum modulus of continuity of βisubscript𝛽𝑖\beta_{i}italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on the training set as in Definition 1, and v0,isubscript𝑣0𝑖v_{0,i}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the bias from the hidden layer to the output layer of the ANN on user i𝑖iitalic_i.

Proof 3.1.

Refer to Appendix 5.2.

3.1.2 Clicking Behaviour Estimation

{tac}

For each user i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ], the input and output training sets are [𝒳p,i𝒳x,i]∈[−1,1]2×mmatrixsubscript𝒳𝑝𝑖subscript𝒳𝑥𝑖superscript112𝑚\begin{bmatrix}\mathcal{X}_{p,i}\\ \mathcal{X}_{x,i}\end{bmatrix}\in[-1,1]^{2\times m}[ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] ∈ [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 × italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, 𝒳y,i∈[0,1]1×msubscript𝒳𝑦𝑖superscript011𝑚\mathcal{X}_{y,i}\in[0,1]^{1\times m}caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 × italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, respectively. We then construct an ANN similarly as for opinion estimation111We omit the details due to space limitations and refer the interested reader to for a detail discussion.. {arxiv} To estimate the clicking behaviour, we proceed similarly as for opinion estimation. For each user i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ], the input and output training sets are

[𝒳p,i𝒳x,i]∈[−1,1]2×m,𝒳y,i∈[0,1]1×m,formulae-sequencematrixsubscript𝒳𝑝𝑖subscript𝒳𝑥𝑖superscript112𝑚subscript𝒳𝑦𝑖superscript011𝑚\begin{bmatrix}\mathcal{X}_{p,i}\\ \mathcal{X}_{x,i}\end{bmatrix}\in[-1,1]^{2\times m},\mathcal{X}_{y,i}\in[0,1]^% {1\times m},[ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] ∈ [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 × italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ [ 0 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 × italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

respectively. Given the recommender system’s personalization of positions to the user’s interests, the i𝑖iitalic_i-th user’s CTR yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT only depends on their steady-state opinion xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the provided position pisubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Hence, we have two input neurons (xi,pisubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖x_{i},p_{i}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) and one neuron in the output layer (yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i}italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). Further, we use 3333 intermediate layers with 5555 neurons. The hyperbolic tangent and the identity are used as activation functions at the intermediate layers and the output layer, respectively.

We now derive an upper bound on the resulting clicking behaviour estimation error ey:=g^⁢(p,x^)−g⁢(p,h⁢(p,d))assignsubscript𝑒𝑦^𝑔𝑝^𝑥𝑔𝑝ℎ𝑝𝑑e_{y}:=\hat{g}(p,\hat{x})-g(p,h(p,d))italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ( italic_p , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) - italic_g ( italic_p , italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) ), where x^^𝑥\hat{x}over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG and g^^𝑔\hat{g}over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG represents the opinion and clicking behaviour learned by the ANN.

Lemma 3.2 (Clicking behaviour estimation error).

Under Assumptions 2–3, the clicking behaviour estimation error is upper-bounded as ∥ey∥≤ϵgdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑒𝑦subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑔\lVert e_{y}\rVert\leq\epsilon_{g}∥ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ≤ italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with

ϵg≤n[\displaystyle\epsilon_{g}\leq\sqrt{n}\Big{[}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ square-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG [ 3⁢supp∈𝒳p,x∈𝒳x⁢∥g⁢(p,x)−g^⁢(p,x)∥∞+2⁢supi∈[n]⁢ωgi⁢(γy)+3formulae-sequence𝑝subscript𝒳𝑝𝑥subscript𝒳𝑥supsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑔𝑝𝑥^𝑔𝑝𝑥limit-from2𝑖delimited-[]𝑛supsubscript𝜔subscript𝑔𝑖subscript𝛾𝑦\displaystyle 3\underset{p\in\mathcal{X}_{p},x\in\mathcal{X}_{x}}{\mathrm{sup}% }\lVert g(p,x)-\hat{g}(p,x)\rVert_{\infty}+2\underset{i\in[n]}{\mathrm{sup}}% \omega_{g_{i}}(\gamma_{y})+3 start_UNDERACCENT italic_p ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_sup end_ARG ∥ italic_g ( italic_p , italic_x ) - over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ( italic_p , italic_x ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 start_UNDERACCENT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_sup end_ARG italic_ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) +
γysupi∈[n]|w0,i|]+Mxϵx+αy,\displaystyle\gamma_{y}\underset{i\in[n]}{\mathrm{sup}}|w_{0,i}|\Big{]}+M_{x}% \epsilon_{x}+\alpha_{y},italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_UNDERACCENT italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ] end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_sup end_ARG | italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | ] + italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , (9)

where supp∈𝒳p,x∈𝒳x⁢∥g⁢(p,x)−g^⁢(p,x)∥∞formulae-sequence𝑝subscript𝒳𝑝𝑥subscript𝒳𝑥supsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝑔𝑝𝑥^𝑔𝑝𝑥\underset{p\in\mathcal{X}_{p},x\in\mathcal{X}_{x}}{\mathrm{sup}}\lVert g(p,x)-% \hat{g}(p,x)\rVert_{\infty}start_UNDERACCENT italic_p ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_sup end_ARG ∥ italic_g ( italic_p , italic_x ) - over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ( italic_p , italic_x ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the maximum estimation error during ANN training, ωgi⁢(γy)subscript𝜔subscript𝑔𝑖subscript𝛾𝑦\omega_{g_{i}}(\gamma_{y})italic_ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) denotes the minimum modulus of continuity of gisubscript𝑔𝑖g_{i}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on the training set as in Definition 1, and w0,isubscript𝑤0𝑖w_{0,i}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT represents the estimated bias weight from the hidden layer to the output layer of the ANN on user i𝑖iitalic_i.

{tac}
Proof 3.3.

The proof is similar to that of Lemma 2 and hence is omitted due to space limitation. We refer the interested reader to the extended version of this paper .

{arxiv}
Proof 3.4.

Refer to Appendix 5.3.

The values γx,γysubscript𝛾𝑥subscript𝛾𝑦\gamma_{x},\gamma_{y}italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the modulus of continuity are properties of the training set and can be determined before training the ANN. The maximum training error term in Lemmas 2, 3.2 can be ascertained after training the ANN. The values v0,i,w0,isubscript𝑣0𝑖subscript𝑤0𝑖v_{0,i},w_{0,i}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are the bias weights from the penultimate to the final layer in the ANN, which are known after training the ANN.

3.2 Level II: Online Sensitivity Learning

To estimate the sensitivity ∇ph⁢(p,d)subscript∇𝑝ℎ𝑝𝑑\nabla_{p}h(p,d)∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) in (7), we develop a Kalman filter, similar to [19]. Given that opinion dynamics and recommendations evolve over time scales that are comparable in magnitude, in order to make our OFO scheme [41] applicable, we introduce an auxiliary mechanism that guarantees time-scale separation between the opinion dynamics and the recommender system updates, see Remark 1.

Note that the input-output sensitivity brings information about interpersonal influence among agents, in fact, if ∇phi⁢j⁢(p,d)≠0subscript∇𝑝subscriptℎ𝑖𝑗𝑝𝑑0\nabla_{p}h_{ij}(p,d)\neq 0∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p , italic_d ) ≠ 0 it means that the position provided to agent j𝑗jitalic_j influences agent i𝑖iitalic_i’s opinion, hence j𝑗jitalic_j and i𝑖iitalic_i are connected over the platform. Thus, by estimating the sensitivity we are able to perform network-aware recommendations. We will see later in this manuscript how this turns out to be beneficial in attenuating polarization.

3.2.1 Kalman Filter for Sensitivity Learning

We denote by ℓ∈ℝn2ℓsuperscriptℝsuperscript𝑛2\ell\in\mathbb{R}^{n^{2}}roman_ℓ ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT the vectorized sensitivity ∇ph⁢(p,d)∈ℝn×nsubscript∇𝑝ℎ𝑝𝑑superscriptℝ𝑛𝑛\nabla_{p}h(p,d)\in\mathbb{R}^{n\times n}∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n × italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, namely, ℓ:=vec⁢(∇ph⁢(p,d))assignℓvecsubscript∇𝑝ℎ𝑝𝑑\ell:=\textrm{vec}(\nabla_{p}h(p,d))roman_ℓ := vec ( ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) ), and model the sensitivity dynamics as the following random walk:

ℓk=ℓk−1+wk−1,superscriptℓ𝑘superscriptℓ𝑘1superscript𝑤𝑘1\ell^{k}=\ell^{k-1}+w^{k-1},roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (10)

where, wk∼𝒩⁢(0n2,Qk)similar-tosuperscript𝑤𝑘𝒩subscript0superscript𝑛2superscript𝑄𝑘w^{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0_{n^{2}},Q^{k})italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ caligraphic_N ( 0 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is the process noise, with Qksuperscript𝑄𝑘Q^{k}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as its corresponding covariance matrix. The measurement model is

Δ⁢xssk+1,k=Δ⁢p~k,k−1⁢ℓk+vk,Δsuperscriptsubscript𝑥ss𝑘1𝑘Δsuperscript~𝑝𝑘𝑘1superscriptℓ𝑘superscript𝑣𝑘\Delta x_{\rm ss}^{k+1,k}=\Delta\tilde{p}^{k,k-1}\ell^{k}+v^{k},roman_Δ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ss end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 , italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_Δ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k , italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (11)

where Δ⁢xssk+1,k:=h⁢(pk,d)−h⁢(pk−1,d)assignΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑥ss𝑘1𝑘ℎsuperscript𝑝𝑘𝑑ℎsuperscript𝑝𝑘1𝑑\Delta x_{\rm ss}^{k+1,k}:=h(p^{k},d)-h(p^{k-1},d)roman_Δ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ss end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 , italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := italic_h ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d ) - italic_h ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d ) is the change in steady-state opinions for a corresponding change in positions Δ⁢pk,k−1:=pk−pk−1assignΔsuperscript𝑝𝑘𝑘1superscript𝑝𝑘superscript𝑝𝑘1\Delta p^{k,k-1}:=p^{k}-p^{k-1}roman_Δ italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k , italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and Δ⁢p~l,m:=Δ⁢(pl,m)⊤⊗In∈ℝn×n2assignΔsuperscript~𝑝𝑙𝑚tensor-productΔsuperscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑙𝑚topsubscript𝐼𝑛superscriptℝ𝑛superscript𝑛2\Delta\tilde{p}^{l,m}:=\Delta(p^{l,m})^{\top}\otimes I_{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{n% \times n^{2}}roman_Δ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l , italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := roman_Δ ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l , italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊗ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n × italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where ⊗tensor-product\otimes⊗ indicates the Kronecker product. The measurement noise is described by vk∼𝒩⁢(0n,Rk)similar-tosuperscript𝑣𝑘𝒩subscript0𝑛superscript𝑅𝑘v^{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0_{n},R^{k})italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ caligraphic_N ( 0 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), where Rksuperscript𝑅𝑘R^{k}italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is its corresponding covariance matrix. This noise accounts for the contribution of the external influence d𝑑ditalic_d to the change of opinions Δ⁢xΔ𝑥\Delta xroman_Δ italic_x.

Remark 3.5.

The measurement model (11) is obtained from a first-order Taylor approximation of the steady-state map around pk−1superscript𝑝𝑘1p^{k-1}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, i.e., h⁢(pk,d)≈h⁢(pk−1,d)+∇ph⁢(pk−1,d)⊤⁢(pk−pk−1)ℎsuperscript𝑝𝑘𝑑ℎsuperscript𝑝𝑘1𝑑subscript∇𝑝ℎsuperscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑘1𝑑topsuperscript𝑝𝑘superscript𝑝𝑘1h(p^{k},d)\approx h(p^{k-1},d)+\nabla_{p}h(p^{k-1},d)^{\top}(p^{k}-p^{k-1})italic_h ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d ) ≈ italic_h ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d ) + ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ). With this intuition, it can be seen that the measurement model is a linear time-variant approximation of the temporal evolution of the sensitivity ∇ph⁢(pk,d)subscript∇𝑝ℎsuperscript𝑝𝑘𝑑\nabla_{p}h(p^{k},d)∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_h ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d ). Note that, the steady-state h⁢(pk,d)ℎsuperscript𝑝𝑘𝑑h(p^{k},d)italic_h ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d ) is reached only asymptotically. Thus, it is common practice [19] to use instead Δ⁢xs⁢sk+1,k=xk+1−xkΔsubscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑘1𝑘𝑠𝑠superscript𝑥𝑘1superscript𝑥𝑘\Delta x^{k+1,k}_{ss}=x^{k+1}-x^{k}roman_Δ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 , italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as the measurement in (11). □□\square□

The posterior update of sensitivity estimates ℓ^ksuperscript^ℓ𝑘\hat{\ell}^{k}over^ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and covariance ΣksuperscriptΣ𝑘\Sigma^{k}roman_Σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are given by

ℓ^ksuperscript^ℓ𝑘\displaystyle\hat{\ell}^{k}over^ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =ℓ^k−1+ζk⁢Kk−1⁢(Δ⁢x^k+1,τi+1−Δ⁢p~k,τi⁢ℓ^k−1)absentsuperscript^ℓ𝑘1superscript𝜁𝑘superscript𝐾𝑘1Δsuperscript^𝑥𝑘1subscript𝜏𝑖1Δsuperscript~𝑝𝑘subscript𝜏𝑖superscript^ℓ𝑘1\displaystyle=\hat{\ell}^{k-1}+\zeta^{k}K^{k-1}\big{(}\Delta\hat{x}^{k+1,\tau_% {i}+1}-\Delta\tilde{p}^{k,\tau_{i}}\hat{\ell}^{k-1}\big{)}= over^ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_ζ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_Δ over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - roman_Δ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )
ΣksuperscriptΣ𝑘\displaystyle\Sigma^{k}roman_Σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =Σk−1+ζk⁢(Qk−Kk−1⁢Δ⁢p~k,τi⁢Σk−1),absentsuperscriptΣ𝑘1superscript𝜁𝑘superscript𝑄𝑘superscript𝐾𝑘1Δsuperscript~𝑝𝑘subscript𝜏𝑖superscriptΣ𝑘1\displaystyle=\Sigma^{k-1}+\zeta^{k}\big{(}Q^{k}-K^{k-1}\Delta\tilde{p}^{k,% \tau_{i}}\Sigma^{k-1}\big{)},= roman_Σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_ζ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Δ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , (12)

where ζ𝜁\zetaitalic_ζ enforces an auxiliary trigger mechanism, with

ζk={1,k=i⁢T0,otherwise.superscript𝜁𝑘cases1𝑘𝑖𝑇0otherwise\zeta^{k}=\Bigg{\{}\begin{array}[]{ll}1,&k=iT\\ 0,&\rm otherwise\end{array}.italic_ζ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = { start_ARRAY start_ROW start_CELL 1 , end_CELL start_CELL italic_k = italic_i italic_T end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 , end_CELL start_CELL roman_otherwise end_CELL end_ROW end_ARRAY .

The trigger mechanism is introduced for the recommender system to update positions close to steady state, see Remark 1, and to collect a sufficient number of clicks to ensure a proper estimate of the CTR needed for opinion estimation. The trigger mechanism is turned on at integer multiples i∈ℕ𝑖ℕi\in\mathbb{N}italic_i ∈ blackboard_N of the time period T𝑇Titalic_T. We define 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T}caligraphic_T as the set of all trigger time instances, with τi∈𝒯subscript𝜏𝑖𝒯\tau_{i}\in\mathcal{T}italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_T representing the most recent trigger time instance prior to k𝑘kitalic_k. Note that the update (3.2.1) uses the opinion estimate x^^𝑥\hat{x}over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG introduced in §3.1.1 rather than the real users’ opinion, with x^k+1=β^⁢(yk,pk)superscript^𝑥𝑘1^𝛽superscript𝑦𝑘superscript𝑝𝑘\hat{x}^{k+1}=\hat{\beta}(y^{k},p^{k})over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG ( italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), where yk:=∑t=τikct/(k−τi+1)assignsuperscript𝑦𝑘superscriptsubscript𝑡subscript𝜏𝑖𝑘superscript𝑐𝑡𝑘subscript𝜏𝑖1y^{k}:=\sum_{t=\tau_{i}}^{k}c^{t}/(k-\tau_{i}+1)italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t = italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / ( italic_k - italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 ) is the CTR since the most recent trigger time instant. Finally, the Kalman filter gain Kksuperscript𝐾𝑘K^{k}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in (3.2.1) is given by

Kk=Σk⁢(Δ⁢p~k,τi)⊤⁢(Rk+Δ⁢p~k,τi⁢Σk⁢(Δ⁢p~k,τi)⊤)−1,superscript𝐾𝑘superscriptΣ𝑘superscriptΔsuperscript~𝑝𝑘subscript𝜏𝑖topsuperscriptsuperscript𝑅𝑘Δsuperscript~𝑝𝑘subscript𝜏𝑖superscriptΣ𝑘superscriptΔsuperscript~𝑝𝑘subscript𝜏𝑖top1K^{k}=\Sigma^{k}(\Delta\tilde{p}^{k,\tau_{i}})^{\top}(R^{k}+\Delta\tilde{p}^{k% ,\tau_{i}}\Sigma^{k}(\Delta\tilde{p}^{k,\tau_{i}})^{\top})^{-1},italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_Σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_Δ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Δ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_Δ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , (13)

with Δ⁢p~k,τiΔsuperscript~𝑝𝑘subscript𝜏𝑖\Delta\tilde{p}^{k,\tau_{i}}roman_Δ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and Rksuperscript𝑅𝑘R^{k}italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as in the measurement model (11). Next, we postulate some regularity assumptions for the process and measurement models.

Assumption 4 (Gaussian noise)

The process and measurement noise w,v𝑤𝑣w,vitalic_w , italic_v are white Gaussian. Moreover, the steady-state opinion estimation error ex=h⁢(p,d)−β^⁢(y,p)subscript𝑒𝑥ℎ𝑝𝑑^𝛽𝑦𝑝e_{x}=h(p,d)-\hat{\beta}(y,p)italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) - over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG ( italic_y , italic_p ) is uncorrelated with w𝑤witalic_w and v𝑣vitalic_v. □□\square□

The assumption of white noise for the process model is standard in the context of sensitivity learning in feedback optimization [19]. Intuitively, the process perturbation determines the degree of trust one puts on the sensitivity estimates. It is also reasonable to assume that the external influence is uncorrelated among users in certain cases, for example the extended FJ model in (2) where d=x0𝑑subscript𝑥0d=x_{0}italic_d = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. We also note that since x^^𝑥\hat{x}over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG is estimated using the ANN, the steady-state estimation error exsubscript𝑒𝑥e_{x}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is not correlated with the process or measurement noises in (10), (11). Under Assumption 4, the covariances simplify as Qk=(σqk)2⁢In2superscript𝑄𝑘superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑞𝑘2subscript𝐼superscript𝑛2Q^{k}=(\sigma_{q}^{k})^{2}I_{n^{2}}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Rk=(σrk)2⁢Insuperscript𝑅𝑘superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑟𝑘2subscript𝐼𝑛R^{k}=(\sigma_{r}^{k})^{2}I_{n}italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for some σqsubscript𝜎𝑞\sigma_{q}italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, σr>0subscript𝜎𝑟0\sigma_{r}>0italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0. The tuning of σq,σrsubscript𝜎𝑞subscript𝜎𝑟\sigma_{q},\sigma_{r}italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, is based on heuristics and is described in Appendix 5.4.

To ensure that the sensitivity is correctly inferred, we must guarantee that the input positions Δ⁢pΔ𝑝\Delta proman_Δ italic_p are persistently exciting (see Definition 2). This translates to Δ⁢pΔ𝑝\Delta proman_Δ italic_p being sufficiently variable in order to explore the underlying user opinion dynamics. To do so, we work under the following assumption.

Assumption 5 (Persistency of excitation)

The inputs Δ⁢pΔ𝑝\Delta proman_Δ italic_p are persistently exciting (see Definition 2) and the trigger mechanism in (3.2.1) is activated at least S+1𝑆1S+1italic_S + 1 times, namely |𝒯|≥S+1𝒯𝑆1|\mathcal{T}|\geq S+1| caligraphic_T | ≥ italic_S + 1. □□\square□

In practice, this assumption can be satisfied by introducing a dither signal in the update rule (6).

3.3 Level III: Gradient Estimation & Optimization

We describe the gradient estimation method for the engagement cost function in (3). We remark that this algorithmic step is needed as the clicking behaviour is unknown. We then describe the OFO update rule from (6), incorporating gradient, sensitivity and state estimation.

3.3.1 Gradient Estimation

To estimate the gradient of the engagement maximization cost φctrsuperscript𝜑ctr\varphi^{\rm ctr}italic_φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, we use the finite forward difference method [42]

∇xφ^ictr⁢(p,x)=φ^ctr⁢(p,x+μ⁢ei)−φ^ctr⁢(p,x)μ,subscript∇𝑥subscriptsuperscript^𝜑ctr𝑖𝑝𝑥superscript^𝜑ctr𝑝𝑥𝜇subscript𝑒𝑖superscript^𝜑ctr𝑝𝑥𝜇\nabla_{x}\hat{\varphi}^{\rm ctr}_{i}(p,x)=\frac{\hat{\varphi}^{\rm ctr}(p,x+% \mu e_{i})-\hat{\varphi}^{\rm ctr}(p,x)}{\mu},∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_φ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p , italic_x ) = divide start_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_φ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p , italic_x + italic_μ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - over^ start_ARG italic_φ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p , italic_x ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_μ end_ARG , (14)
∇pφ^ictr⁢(p,x)=φ^ctr⁢(p+μ⁢ei,x)−φ^ctr⁢(p,x)μ,subscript∇𝑝subscriptsuperscript^𝜑ctr𝑖𝑝𝑥superscript^𝜑ctr𝑝𝜇subscript𝑒𝑖𝑥superscript^𝜑ctr𝑝𝑥𝜇\nabla_{p}\hat{\varphi}^{\rm ctr}_{i}(p,x)=\frac{\hat{\varphi}^{\rm ctr}(p+\mu e% _{i},x)-\hat{\varphi}^{\rm ctr}(p,x)}{\mu},∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_φ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p , italic_x ) = divide start_ARG over^ start_ARG italic_φ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p + italic_μ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x ) - over^ start_ARG italic_φ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p , italic_x ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_μ end_ARG , (15)

where ∇jφ^ictr,j∈{p,x}subscript∇𝑗subscriptsuperscript^𝜑ctr𝑖𝑗𝑝𝑥\nabla_{j}\hat{\varphi}^{\rm ctr}_{i},j\in\{p,x\}∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_φ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_j ∈ { italic_p , italic_x } denotes the i𝑖iitalic_i-th entry of the gradient, ei∈ℝnsubscript𝑒𝑖superscriptℝ𝑛e_{i}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT refers to the i𝑖iitalic_i-th vector of the canonical basis of ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and μ𝜇\muitalic_μ is a smoothing parameter. Note that in the two-point gradient estimation, we do not actuate the opinion dynamics twice but rather use the engagement cost function estimate φ^ctr⁢(p,x)=−1n⊤⁢g^⁢(p,x)superscript^𝜑ctr𝑝𝑥superscriptsubscript1𝑛top^𝑔𝑝𝑥\hat{\varphi}^{\rm ctr}(p,x)=-1_{n}^{\top}\hat{g}(p,x)over^ start_ARG italic_φ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p , italic_x ) = - 1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ( italic_p , italic_x ) as described in §3.1.2.

The smoothing parameter μ𝜇\muitalic_μ is chosen small enough so that the gradient estimate provides a good approximation of the true value. However, choosing μ𝜇\muitalic_μ in (14)–(15) too small can lead to numerical instability, as formalized in the following.

Lemma 3.6 (Gradient estimation error).

Under Assumptions 2–3, the gradient estimation error is upper bounded as

∥∇jφ^ctr−∇jφctr∥≤12⁢Lx⁢μ+2⁢n⁢ϵgμ,j∈{x,p}.formulae-sequencedelimited-∥∥subscript∇𝑗superscript^𝜑ctrsubscript∇𝑗superscript𝜑ctr12subscript𝐿𝑥𝜇2𝑛subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑔𝜇𝑗𝑥𝑝\lVert\nabla_{j}\hat{\varphi}^{\rm ctr}-\nabla_{j}\varphi^{\rm ctr}\rVert\leq% \frac{1}{2}L_{x}\mu+2\frac{\sqrt{n}\epsilon_{g}}{\mu},\quad j\in\{x,p\}.∥ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_φ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ ≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_μ + 2 divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_μ end_ARG , italic_j ∈ { italic_x , italic_p } .

The upper bound attains its lowest value 2⁢n3/4⁢ϵg⁢Lj2superscript𝑛34subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑔subscript𝐿𝑗2n^{3/4}\sqrt{\epsilon_{g}L_{j}}2 italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 / 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT square-root start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG at μ∗=2⁢n1/4⁢ϵg/Ljsuperscript𝜇2superscript𝑛14subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑔subscript𝐿𝑗\mu^{*}=2n^{1/4}\sqrt{{\epsilon_{g}}/{L_{j}}}italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 2 italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT square-root start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG, with j∈{x,p}𝑗𝑥𝑝j\in\{x,p\}italic_j ∈ { italic_x , italic_p }.

Proof 3.7.

Refer to Appendix 5.5.

3.3.2 Projected Gradient Descent Algorithm

We now present the projected-gradient update in (6) augmented with sensitivity, state, and gradient estimations. The augmented update reads compactly as

pk+1=Π[−1,1]n⁢[pk−ζk⁢η⁢Φ^k],superscript𝑝𝑘1subscriptΠsuperscript11𝑛delimited-[]superscript𝑝𝑘superscript𝜁𝑘𝜂superscript^Φ𝑘p^{k+1}=\Pi_{[-1,1]^{n}}\Big{[}p^{k}-\zeta^{k}\eta\,\hat{\Phi}^{k}\Big{]},italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_ζ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_η over^ start_ARG roman_Φ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] , (16)

where the gradient surrogate Φ^^Φ\hat{\Phi}over^ start_ARG roman_Φ end_ARG is constructed by combining sensitivity, opinion, and gradient estimates as

Φ^k=superscript^Φ𝑘absent\displaystyle\hat{\Phi}^{k}=over^ start_ARG roman_Φ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ∇pφ^ctr⁢(pk,x^k+1)+(H^k)⊤⁢∇xφ^ctr⁢(pk,x^k+1)subscript∇𝑝superscript^𝜑ctrsuperscript𝑝𝑘superscript^𝑥𝑘1superscriptsuperscript^𝐻𝑘topsubscript∇𝑥superscript^𝜑ctrsuperscript𝑝𝑘superscript^𝑥𝑘1\displaystyle\nabla_{p}\hat{\varphi}^{\rm ctr}(p^{k},\hat{x}^{k+1})+(\hat{H}^{% k})^{\top}\nabla_{x}\hat{\varphi}^{\rm ctr}(p^{k},\hat{x}^{k+1})∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_φ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + ( over^ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_φ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )
+γ⁢(H^k)⊤⁢∇xφpol⁢(x^k+1)−wpek/η,𝛾superscriptsuperscript^𝐻𝑘topsubscript∇𝑥superscript𝜑polsuperscript^𝑥𝑘1superscriptsubscript𝑤pe𝑘𝜂\displaystyle+\gamma(\hat{H}^{k})^{\top}\nabla_{x}\varphi^{\rm pol}(\hat{x}^{k% +1})-w_{\rm pe}^{k}/\eta,+ italic_γ ( over^ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_pol end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_pe end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_η , (17)

where H^k:=∇ph^⁢(pk,d)assignsuperscript^𝐻𝑘subscript∇𝑝^ℎsuperscript𝑝𝑘𝑑\hat{H}^{k}:=\nabla_{p}\hat{h}(p^{k},d)over^ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_h end_ARG ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d ) is the sensitivity estimate at time k𝑘kitalic_k. The additional term wpek∼𝒩⁢(0n,σpe2⁢In)similar-tosuperscriptsubscript𝑤pe𝑘𝒩subscript0𝑛superscriptsubscript𝜎pe2subscript𝐼𝑛w_{\rm pe}^{k}\sim\mathcal{N}(0_{n},\sigma_{\rm pe}^{2}I_{n})italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_pe end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ caligraphic_N ( 0 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_pe end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is a dither signal that ensures persistency of excitation of the inputs (Assumption 5).

In Algorithm 1, we summarize the pseudo-code of the proposed recommender system design. In the offline phase, training of the neural network is carried out for opinion and clicking behaviour estimation. In the online phase, a new sensitivity estimate is generated and new positions are provided to the users periodically, every T𝑇Titalic_T time steps.

3.4 Closed-loop Convergence Guarantees

Here, we establish convergence guarantees for the sensitivity estimation process (3.2.1) and for the closed-loop interconnection between the opinions and recommendations. Before stating the formal results, we make some important observations regarding our opinion estimation technique and its implication on the closed-loop convergence analysis.

In our problem setup, the measurement information at each time instant (i.e., a single click/no click data), is not rich enough to produce accurate estimates for the users’ real-time opinion. As shown in Algorithm 1, the opinion estimation is instead carried out using the CTR recorded on multiple recommendations with a constant position since the previous trigger instant. In light of the exponential stability of the opinion dynamics (i.e., Assumption 1), the resulting estimate at the end of each trigger period is, in practice, close to an estimate of the steady-state opinion h⁢(pk,d)ℎsuperscript𝑝𝑘𝑑h(p^{k},d)italic_h ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d ). This approach is therefore substantially different from real-time state estimation [21]. Thus, as we directly estimate steady-state opinions at each trigger instant, we can greatly simplify our closed-loop stability analysis by treating the opinion dynamics as a static mapping. Also note that as the trigger period T𝑇Titalic_T increases, the resulting CTR offers a better approximation of the CTR in expectation 𝔼⁢[g⁢(p,x)]𝔼delimited-[]𝑔𝑝𝑥\mathbb{E}\big{[}g(p,x)\big{]}blackboard_E [ italic_g ( italic_p , italic_x ) ]. The modeling errors θx,αysubscript𝜃𝑥subscript𝛼𝑦\theta_{x},\alpha_{y}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in Lemma 2, 3.2 exist due to a finite time horizon T𝑇Titalic_T and reduces as T𝑇Titalic_T increases.

Now, we state the main convergence result with respect to the sensitivity estimation error.

Theorem 3.8 (Sensitivity estimate convergence).

Under Assumptions 1, 4, and 5, the sensitivity estimation error ek:=ℓk−ℓ^kassignsuperscript𝑒𝑘superscriptℓ𝑘superscript^ℓ𝑘e^{k}:=\ell^{k}-\hat{\ell}^{k}italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - over^ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT has bias and variance bounded in norm, i.e., there exist positive constants c1,c2,Cf<∞subscript𝑐1subscript𝑐2subscript𝐶𝑓c_{1},c_{2},C_{f}<\inftyitalic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < ∞ and ξ∈(0,1)𝜉01\xi\in(0,1)italic_ξ ∈ ( 0 , 1 ) such that

∥𝔼⁢[ek]∥delimited-∥∥𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑒𝑘\displaystyle\lVert\mathbb{E}[e^{k}]\rVert∥ blackboard_E [ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ∥ ≤2⁢Km⁢ϵx/(1−c1⁢ξc2⁢T)+(c1⁢ξc2⁢T)|𝒯|⁢∥𝔼⁢[e0]∥absent2subscript𝐾𝑚subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑥1subscript𝑐1superscript𝜉subscript𝑐2𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑐1superscript𝜉subscript𝑐2𝑇𝒯delimited-∥∥𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑒0\displaystyle\leq 2K_{m}\epsilon_{x}/(1-c_{1}\xi^{c_{2}T})+(c_{1}\xi^{c_{2}T})% ^{|\mathcal{T}|}\lVert\mathbb{E}[e^{0}]\rVert≤ 2 italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / ( 1 - italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | caligraphic_T | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ blackboard_E [ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ∥
𝔼⁢[∥ek∥2]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝑒𝑘2\displaystyle\mathbb{E}\Big{[}\lVert e^{k}\rVert^{2}\Big{]}blackboard_E [ ∥ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ≤Cf+(c1⁢ξc2⁢T)2⁢|𝒯|⁢𝔼⁢[∥e0∥2]absentsubscript𝐶𝑓superscriptsubscript𝑐1superscript𝜉subscript𝑐2𝑇2𝒯𝔼delimited-[]superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝑒02\displaystyle\leq C_{f}+(c_{1}\xi^{c_{2}T})^{2|\mathcal{T}|}\mathbb{E}\Big{[}% \lVert e^{0}\rVert^{2}\Big{]}≤ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 | caligraphic_T | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ ∥ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ]

where
