Proof 3.9.

Refer to Appendix 5.6.

Note that both bias and variance upper bounds depend on the opinion estimation error ϵxsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑥\epsilon_{x}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Further, note that increasing the sampling period T𝑇Titalic_T reduces the bias and variance error through the term 1−c1⁢ξc2⁢T1subscript𝑐1superscript𝜉subscript𝑐2𝑇1-c_{1}\xi^{c_{2}T}1 - italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. This is expected as increasing T𝑇Titalic_T guarantees greater time-scale separation between opinion dynamics and recommendations. Finally, the upper bound on the sensitivity error variance is proportional to the noise variance of the opinions through the term σ¯r2superscriptsubscript¯𝜎𝑟2\overline{\sigma}_{r}^{2}over¯ start_ARG italic_σ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

To quantify performance on the recommendations, we use the fixed-point residual mapping [43, Eq. (5)]

𝒢⁢(p):=1η⁢(p−Π[−1,1]n⁢[p−η⁢Φ⁢(p,h⁢(p,d))]).assign𝒢𝑝1𝜂𝑝subscriptΠsuperscript11𝑛delimited-[]𝑝𝜂Φ𝑝ℎ𝑝𝑑\mathcal{G}(p):=\frac{1}{\eta}\Big{(}p-\Pi_{[-1,1]^{n}}\big{[}p-\eta\Phi(p,h(p% ,d))\big{]}\Big{)}.caligraphic_G ( italic_p ) := divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_η end_ARG ( italic_p - roman_Π start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ italic_p - italic_η roman_Φ ( italic_p , italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) ) ] ) . (18)

The fixed-point residual mapping is zero at any critical point of (5), and is a common metric to quantify convergence of iterative algorithms in non-convex regimes [26].

The following theorem shows the convergence of the closed-loop system, combining Levels I, II, and III in Figure 2, using the second moment of the fixed-point residual mapping. Since the problem is non-convex, the trajectories of {pk}k=0Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑘𝑘0𝑁\{p^{k}\}_{k=0}^{N}{ italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT vary across each trial. Thus, it is essential to evaluate ∥𝒢⁢(pk)∥delimited-∥∥𝒢superscript𝑝𝑘\lVert\mathcal{G}(p^{k})\rVert∥ caligraphic_G ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∥ with its expectation. Moreover, we compute the average of this metric over all the trigger time instances to reflect the average performance of Algorithm 1 over the time in which recommendations are provided. The theoretical bound is only computed over the trigger time instances since the positions remain constant between two trigger instances, and so does the residual ∥𝒢⁢(pk)∥delimited-∥∥𝒢superscript𝑝𝑘\lVert\mathcal{G}(p^{k})\rVert∥ caligraphic_G ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∥.

Theorem 3.10 (Closed-loop convergence).

Let Assumptions 1–5 hold. For any η∈(0,12⁢L′)𝜂012superscript𝐿′\eta\in(0,\frac{1}{2L^{\prime}})italic_η ∈ ( 0 , divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) and μ∗=2⁢n1/4⁢ϵg/Lj,j∈{p,x}formulae-sequencesuperscript𝜇2superscript𝑛14subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑔subscript𝐿𝑗𝑗𝑝𝑥\mu^{*}=2n^{1/4}\sqrt{{\epsilon_{g}}/{L_{j}}},j\in\{p,x\}italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 2 italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT square-root start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG , italic_j ∈ { italic_p , italic_x }, the sequence {pk}k∈ℕsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑘𝑘ℕ\{p^{k}\}_{k\in\mathbb{N}}{ italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k ∈ blackboard_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT generated by (16) satisfies

1|𝒯|⁢∑l∈𝒯l≤k𝔼⁢[∥𝒢⁢(pl)∥2]1𝒯subscript𝑙𝑘𝑙𝒯𝔼delimited-[]superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝒢superscript𝑝𝑙2\displaystyle\frac{1}{|\mathcal{T}|}\sum_{\underset{l\leq k}{l\in\mathcal{T}}}% \mathbb{E}\Big{[}\lVert\mathcal{G}(p^{l})\rVert^{2}\Big{]}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG | caligraphic_T | end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_UNDERACCENT italic_l ≤ italic_k end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG italic_l ∈ caligraphic_T end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E [ ∥ caligraphic_G ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ≤K1,∀k≥Tformulae-sequenceabsentsubscript𝐾1for-all𝑘𝑇\displaystyle\leq K_{1},\quad\forall k\geq T≤ italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∀ italic_k ≥ italic_T (19)

In there, L′=Lp+L2⁢(Lx+2)superscript𝐿′subscript𝐿𝑝superscript𝐿2subscript𝐿𝑥2L^{\prime}=L_{p}+L^{2}(L_{x}+2)italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 ) is the Lipschitz constant of the gradient Φ⁢(⋅,h⁢(⋅,d))Φ⋅ℎ⋅𝑑\Phi(\cdot,h(\cdot,d))roman_Φ ( ⋅ , italic_h ( ⋅ , italic_d ) ), and φ∗=infp∈[−1,1]n⁢φ⁢(p,h⁢(p,d))>−nsuperscript𝜑subscriptinf𝑝superscript11𝑛𝜑𝑝ℎ𝑝𝑑𝑛\varphi^{*}={\mathrm{inf}}_{p\in[-1,1]^{n}}\varphi(p,h(p,d))>-nitalic_φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_inf start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p ∈ [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ ( italic_p , italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) ) > - italic_n is the cost function value at a locally optimal solution.

Proof 3.11.

Refer to Appendix 5.15.

Note that an upper bound on the minimum of ∥𝒢⁢(pk)∥delimited-∥∥𝒢superscript𝑝𝑘\lVert\mathcal{G}(p^{k})\rVert∥ caligraphic_G ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∥ can be inferred from (19), through the inequality 𝔼⁢[minl∈𝒯⁢∥𝒢⁢(pl)∥2]≤𝔼⁢[1|𝒯|⁢∑l∈𝒯∥𝒢⁢(pl)∥2]=1|𝒯|⁢𝔼⁢[∑l∈𝒯∥𝒢⁢(pl)∥2]𝔼delimited-[]𝑙𝒯minsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥𝒢superscript𝑝𝑙2𝔼delimited-[]1𝒯subscript𝑙𝒯superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝒢superscript𝑝𝑙21𝒯𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝑙𝒯superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝒢superscript𝑝𝑙2\mathbb{E}\Big{[}\underset{l\in\mathcal{T}}{\mathrm{min}}\lVert\mathcal{G}(p^{% l})\rVert^{2}\Big{]}\leq\mathbb{E}\Big{[}\frac{1}{|\mathcal{T}|}\sum_{l\in% \mathcal{T}}\lVert\mathcal{G}(p^{l})\rVert^{2}\Big{]}=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{T}|}% \mathbb{E}\Big{[}\sum_{l\in\mathcal{T}}\lVert\mathcal{G}(p^{l})\rVert^{2}\Big{]}blackboard_E [ start_UNDERACCENT italic_l ∈ caligraphic_T end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_min end_ARG ∥ caligraphic_G ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ≤ blackboard_E [ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG | caligraphic_T | end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l ∈ caligraphic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ caligraphic_G ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG | caligraphic_T | end_ARG blackboard_E [ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l ∈ caligraphic_T end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ caligraphic_G ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ], see [23, Remark 5]. Thus, intuitively, the bound in (19) describes the maximum possible minimum gap between the trajectory {pk,h⁢(pk,d)}k=0Nsuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑘ℎsuperscript𝑝𝑘𝑑𝑘0𝑁\{p^{k},h(p^{k},d)\}_{k=0}^{N}{ italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT obtained using Algorithm 1 and a local minima (p∗,h⁢(p∗,d))superscript𝑝ℎsuperscript𝑝𝑑(p^{*},h(p^{*},d))( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d ) ).

The bound K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT shows that achieving an accurate solution of (5), i.e., a local minima (p∗,h⁢(p∗,d))superscript𝑝ℎsuperscript𝑝𝑑(p^{*},h(p^{*},d))( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d ) ), is limited by the deviation of the initial cost at (p0,h⁢(p0,d))superscript𝑝0ℎsuperscript𝑝0𝑑(p^{0},h(p^{0},d))( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_h ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_d ) ) from the optimal one φ∗superscript𝜑\varphi^{*}italic_φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT (i.e., the term κ1subscript𝜅1\kappa_{1}italic_κ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), the polarization and engagement gradient estimation errors (i.e., the terms κ2,κ3subscript𝜅2subscript𝜅3\kappa_{2},\kappa_{3}italic_κ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_κ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively) including both opinion and clicking behaviour estimation errors, the variance of the dither signal σpe2superscriptsubscript𝜎pe2\sigma_{\rm pe}^{2}italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_pe end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and the sensitivity estimation error variance 𝔼⁢[∥el∥2]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝑒𝑙2\mathbb{E}[\lVert e^{l}\rVert^{2}]blackboard_E [ ∥ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ].

Corollary 3.12 (Asymptotic convergence).

As |𝒯|→∞→𝒯|\mathcal{T}|\rightarrow\infty| caligraphic_T | → ∞, the upper bound K1subscript𝐾1K_{1}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in in Theorem 3.10 approaches K2subscript𝐾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, given by

K2=61−2⁢η⁢L′(\displaystyle K_{2}=\frac{6}{1-2\eta L^{\prime}}\Bigg{(}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 6 end_ARG start_ARG 1 - 2 italic_η italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ( 2⁢Cf⁢(2⁢n⁢γ2+Mx2+4⁢n3/2⁢ϵg⁢Lx)+limit-from2subscript𝐶𝑓2𝑛superscript𝛾2superscriptsubscript𝑀𝑥24superscript𝑛32subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑔subscript𝐿𝑥\displaystyle 2C_{f}(2n\gamma^{2}+M_{x}^{2}+4n^{3/2}\epsilon_{g}L_{x})+2 italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 2 italic_n italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 4 italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) +
4(κ2+κ3)+σpe2η2)\displaystyle 4(\kappa_{2}+\kappa_{3})+\frac{\sigma_{\rm pe}^{2}}{\eta^{2}}% \Bigg{)}4 ( italic_κ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_κ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + divide start_ARG italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_pe end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_η start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG )
Proof 3.13.

Refer to Appendix 5.15.

From K2subscript𝐾2K_{2}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we observe that the asymptotic accuracy is limited by a combination of gradient estimation errors, which include opinion and clicking behaviour estimation (i.e., the terms κ2,κ3subscript𝜅2subscript𝜅3\kappa_{2},\kappa_{3}italic_κ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_κ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), the sensitivity estimation error, and the variance of the dither signal σpe2superscriptsubscript𝜎pe2\sigma_{\rm pe}^{2}italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_pe end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Moreover, the upper-bound of the average of the variance of sensitivity estimation error over the trigger time instances approaches Cfsubscript𝐶𝑓C_{f}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the asymptotic sensitivity error variance.

4 Numerical Case Studies

4.1 Opinion Dynamics and Clicking Behaviour

We assume the opinions of the users on the platform evolve according to the FJ model as in Example 1, i.e.,

xk+1=(In−Γp−Γd)⁢A⁢xk+Γp⁢pk+Γd⁢d.superscript𝑥𝑘1subscript𝐼𝑛subscriptΓ𝑝subscriptΓ𝑑𝐴superscript𝑥𝑘subscriptΓ𝑝superscript𝑝𝑘subscriptΓ𝑑𝑑x^{k+1}=(I_{n}-\Gamma_{p}-\Gamma_{d})Ax^{k}+\Gamma_{p}p^{k}+\Gamma_{d}d.italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - roman_Γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - roman_Γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) italic_A italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + roman_Γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d .

Further, we consider users with two different clicking behaviours: confirmation bias towards extreme positions, CAsubscript𝐶𝐴C_{A}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, defined as in Example 2, and confirmation bias towards any position, CBsubscript𝐶𝐵C_{B}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, wherein the click event is given by

ci∼ℬ⁢(12+12⁢e−4⁢(xi−pi)2).similar-tosubscript𝑐𝑖ℬ1212superscript𝑒4superscriptsubscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖2c_{i}\sim\mathcal{B}\Big{(}\frac{1}{2}+\frac{1}{2}e^{-4(x_{i}-p_{i})^{2}}\Big{% )}.italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∼ caligraphic_B ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 4 ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (20)

Note that the choice of these clicking behaviors make the steady-state optimization problem (5) non-convex.

As a proof of concept, we consider a platform with n=15𝑛15n=15italic_n = 15 users. We generate the adjacency matrix A𝐴Aitalic_A with some random entries zero and other entries sampled from 𝒰⁢[0,1]𝒰01\mathcal{U}[0,1]caligraphic_U [ 0 , 1 ]222This ensures that the non-zero weights in the graph are not insignificant. such that A⁢𝟏n≤𝟏n𝐴subscript1𝑛subscript1𝑛A\mathbf{1}_{n}\leq\mathbf{1}_{n}italic_A bold_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ bold_1 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Thus, the resulting graph need not be strongly connected. We generate the initial opinions as x0∼𝒰⁢[−1,1]nsimilar-tosuperscript𝑥0𝒰superscript11𝑛x^{0}\sim\mathcal{U}[-1,1]^{n}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∼ caligraphic_U [ - 1 , 1 ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Moreover, we set Γd=0.5⁢diag⁢[|x0|]subscriptΓ𝑑0.5diagdelimited-[]superscript𝑥0\Gamma_{d}=0.5\mathrm{diag}[|x^{0}|]roman_Γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.5 roman_diag [ | italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | ]. This choice of ΓdsubscriptΓ𝑑\Gamma_{d}roman_Γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT indicates that the users who hold initial extreme opinions tend to be more stubborn. The external influence d𝑑ditalic_d is modelled as a prejudice term defined as the initial opinion x0superscript𝑥0x^{0}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Further, ΓpsubscriptΓ𝑝\Gamma_{p}roman_Γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is drawn from 𝒟[10−2,0.5]nsuperscriptsubscript𝒟superscript1020.5𝑛\mathcal{D}_{[10^{-2},0.5]}^{n}caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT [ 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , 0.5 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT so that all users are affected by the recommendations. To incorporate diversity in clicking behaviours, we randomly assign 8888 users to follow clicking behaviour CAsubscript𝐶𝐴C_{A}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the remaining ones follow CBsubscript𝐶𝐵C_{B}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

4.2 Experimental Setting and Hyperparameter Selection

In the offline phase (Algorithm 2 in Appendix 5.1), we train the neural network for opinion and clicking behaviour estimation with m=375𝑚375m=375italic_m = 375 training and 125125125125 testing points, simulation time N=100𝑁100N=100italic_N = 100 and trigger period T=60𝑇60T=60italic_T = 60, with the clicks being recorded in the duration k∈[N−T,N]𝑘𝑁𝑇𝑁k\in[N-T,N]italic_k ∈ [ italic_N - italic_T , italic_N ]. We set the trade-off factor γ=1𝛾1\gamma=1italic_γ = 1 in (3), thus giving equal importance to engagement maximization and polarization mitigation.

In the online phase, we choose σpe=0.07subscript𝜎pe0.07\sigma_{\text{pe}}=0.07italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT pe end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.07 in (16) for the first N/5𝑁5N/5italic_N / 5 time steps to facilitate sensitivity estimation333Sensitivity estimation can be halted after convergence on its entries. and network learning, and σpe=0subscript𝜎pe0\sigma_{\text{pe}}=0italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT pe end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 afterwards to favor accurate recommendations. In the Kalman filter (3.2.1), we initialize ℓ^0=0.5⁢vec⁢(In)superscript^ℓ00.5vecsubscript𝐼𝑛\hat{\ell}^{0}=0.5{\rm vec}(I_{n})over^ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.5 roman_vec ( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and Σ0=In2superscriptΣ0subscript𝐼superscript𝑛2\Sigma^{0}=I_{n^{2}}roman_Σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For gradient estimation in (14)–(15), we set the smoothing parameter μ=0.1𝜇0.1\mu=0.1italic_μ = 0.1. While tuning the process noise standard deviation, we set the tuning parameter M𝑀Mitalic_M in (21) as M=10𝑀10M=10italic_M = 10. Further, we start with neutral recommendations, i.e., p0=0nsuperscript𝑝0subscript0𝑛p^{0}=0_{n}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and consider a periodic trigger with period T=60𝑇60T=60italic_T = 60. For the polarization cost φpolsuperscript𝜑pol\varphi^{\rm pol}italic_φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_pol end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in (4), we set ϵ1=−0.5subscriptitalic-ϵ10.5\epsilon_{1}=-0.5italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - 0.5 and ϵ2=0.5subscriptitalic-ϵ20.5\epsilon_{2}=0.5italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.5. All the simulations are conducted for N=2.5⋅104𝑁⋅2.5superscript104N=2.5\cdot 10^{4}italic_N = 2.5 ⋅ 10 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT time instances and over 50505050 Monte-Carlo trials. Since clicks are stochastic, the sequence of clicks varies across each trial. Moreover, the dither signal wpesubscript𝑤pew_{\rm pe}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_pe end_POSTSUBSCRIPT sequence varies across each trial, thus leading to different sensitivity estimates.

4.3 Architecture Comparisons

In this section, we compare Algorithm 1 against other similar OFO approaches that benefit from more information.

In Table 2, we summarize all the methods used for comparison and their attributes. In particular, for the oracle (method M1subscript𝑀1M_{1}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), we employ the standard projected-gradient controller (6), wherein opinions can be directly measured, and the sensitivity and users’ clicking behavior are both known.

Method M2subscript𝑀2M_{2}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT uses online sensitivity estimation. Method M3subscript𝑀3M_{3}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT uses opinion as well as sensitivity estimation. Finally, method M4subscript𝑀4M_{4}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT corresponds to Algorithm 1, and includes also clicking behaviour and gradient estimation. All the methods’ architecture can be extracted from Figure 2 by replacing or removing some of the blocks. Method M1subscript𝑀1M_{1}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT would not require the ANN in Level-1, the Kalman filter in Level-2 and gradient estimation in Level-3. Method M2subscript𝑀2M_{2}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT would not require the ANN and gradient estimation. Method M3subscript𝑀3M_{3}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT would need the ANN only for opinion estimation, but does not require gradient estimation.

Figure 3 shows that convergence is empirically established in all the methods through the fixed-point residual mapping norm ∥𝒢⁢(pk)∥2superscriptdelimited-∥∥𝒢superscript𝑝𝑘2\lVert\mathcal{G}(p^{k})\rVert^{2}∥ caligraphic_G ( italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. In particular, for methods that involve sensitivity estimation (i.e., M2−M4subscript𝑀2subscript𝑀4M_{2}-M_{4}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT), we observe a higher fluctuation for the first N/5𝑁5N/5italic_N / 5 time instances due to the effect of the dither signal σpesubscript𝜎pe\sigma_{\text{pe}}italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT pe end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Our proposed method offers slightly inferior performances compared to the others, which is unsurprising as it is completely data-driven.

In Figure 4, we illustrate the relative sensitivity estimation error. It is expected that method M2subscript𝑀2M_{2}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT performs better than M3,M4subscript𝑀3subscript𝑀4M_{3},M_{4}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as the opinions are known in real time. However, the methods that involve steady-state opinion estimation, M3,M4subscript𝑀3subscript𝑀4M_{3},M_{4}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, still show comparable performance. This is due to accurate opinion estimation, as can be seen from Figure 5, where we show the opinion estimates for four randomly chosen users, along with their true values. Finally, Figure 6, shows the effect of γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ in (3) on the trade-off between engagement maximization and polarization mitigation. As expected, increasing γ𝛾\gammaitalic_γ, turns into a polarization cost reduction. However, the loss in engagement is not significant. This is due to the fact that roughly half of the agents follow clicking behaviour CBsubscript𝐶𝐵C_{B}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and hence still get engaged by the non-extreme content that promotes polarization mitigation. A more significant engagement loss would be expected if all the users were to be engaged by extreme content only [9].

4.4 Impact of Network-aware Recommendations

In this case study, we showcase the impact of providing network-aware recommendations compared to individual, decoupled recommendations. To achieve this, we compare our approach with two network-agnostic methods: (i) the recommender system described in [9], and (ii) a naive version of our OFO-based recommender design.

The design in [9] provides recommendations with exclusively extreme positions (i.e., pi=±1subscript𝑝𝑖plus-or-minus1p_{i}=\pm 1italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ± 1) to each user independently. The position is calculated based on the user’s individual clicking history. Specifically, if a user more frequently clicks on +11+1+ 1 (or −11-1- 1) positions, the system will provide +11+1+ 1 (or −11-1- 1) positions with high probability. Conversely, if the user shows an equal likelihood of clicking on both +11+1+ 1 and −11-1- 1 positions, the recommendations will be random. It’s important to note that the comparison with the method in [9] is not entirely equitable in terms of methodology: their approach relies solely on extreme positions and does not target polarization reduction as an objective. However, we include this comparison because, to the best of our knowledge, it is the only model-free, opinion agnostic, systems-theory-based recommender design available.

The second method considered for comparison is a network-agnostic version of our recommender system design summarized in Algorithm 1. We will refer to this method as naive OFO. Specifically, for each user i∈[n]𝑖delimited-[]𝑛i\in[n]italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ], we use a local ANN for opinion estimation that is trained using local positions and acceptance ratio, i.e., x^i=β^i⁢(yi,pi)subscript^𝑥𝑖subscript^𝛽𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖\hat{x}_{i}=\hat{\beta}_{i}(y_{i},p_{i})over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) rather than β^i⁢(yi,p)subscript^𝛽𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖𝑝\hat{\beta}_{i}(y_{i},p)over^ start_ARG italic_β end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_y start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_p ). Further, we do not carry out sensitivity estimation and instead use a constant diagonal sensitivity H^∈𝒟(0,0.5]n^𝐻superscriptsubscript𝒟00.5𝑛\hat{H}\in\mathcal{D}_{(0,0.5]}^{n}over^ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG ∈ caligraphic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( 0 , 0.5 ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in (17). The rationale behind this design choice is that if the network did not contribute to engagement maximization and/or polarization mitigation, a diagonal H^^𝐻\hat{H}over^ start_ARG italic_H end_ARG would yield the same performance as our network-aware approach.

We compare the performance of our recommender system with the other decoupled methods in terms of final mean CTR J:=∑k=N−T+1N∥ck∥1/(n⁢T)assign𝐽superscriptsubscript𝑘𝑁𝑇1𝑁subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝑐𝑘1𝑛𝑇J:=\sum_{k=N-T+1}^{N}\lVert c^{k}\rVert_{1}/(nT)italic_J := ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = italic_N - italic_T + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ italic_c start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / ( italic_n italic_T ) and final polarization cost φpol⁢(xN)superscript𝜑polsuperscript𝑥𝑁\varphi^{\rm pol}(x^{N})italic_φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_pol end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) in Figure 7 and the fixed point residual mapping in Figure 8. In Figure 7, we observe that our proposed algorithm achieves a slightly higher (∼1.3%similar-toabsentpercent1.3\sim 1.3\%∼ 1.3 %) user engagement compared to its naive implementation and results in a lower polarization cost (∼9.3%similar-toabsentpercent9.3\sim 9.3\%∼ 9.3 %). Thus, network-aware recommendations effectively reduce polarization while maintaining high user engagement. This performance improvement is further illustrated in Figure 8, which depicts the temporal evolution of the fixed-point residuals. This result is unsurprising since polarization is a global network metric, whereas engagement maximization can be addressed individually by tailoring recommended content for each user.

Note that the recommender design in [9] employs only extreme recommendations, naturally leading to higher polarization costs, as shown in Figure 7(b). Furthermore, it results in lower user engagement compared to both our algorithm and the naive method. This is because some users in the network are assigned clicking behavior CBsubscript𝐶𝐵C_{B}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for which extreme recommendations do not necessarily increase engagement.

5 Conclusion

We introduced a novel recommender system algorithm based on online feedback optimization that balances the trade-off between maximizing user engagement (CTR) and minimizing polarization. By integrating auxiliary estimation blocks, our approach overcomes the limitations of existing OFO designs, which require unavailable real-time data, and instead relies solely on click data. We established theoretical guarantees for closed-loop stability and validated our design through numerical simulations using an extended FJ model. Our results demonstrated the impact of network-awareness in reducing polarization while maintaining high engagement.

Future compelling research directions include relaxing the smoothness assumptions for clicking behavior and exploring alternative interest drivers, such as repulsion, beyond confirmation bias. Parameter estimation for clicking behavior could also be refined by using a grey-box model instead of a purely black-box approach. Additionally, investigating the impact of different graph topologies on polarization and developing distributed algorithms for more efficient sensitivity estimation in large-scale networks would be valuable. Lastly, we hope our network-centered approach contributes to the literature on mitigating opinion polarization through algorithmic systems.

Appendix

5.1 Training Data

The training of the neural network is carried out offline via feed-forward and back-propagation [44]. Algorithm 2, provides the pseudo-code to acquire the training data.

For each training sample k∈[m]𝑘delimited-[]𝑚k\in[m]italic_k ∈ [ italic_m ], we provide news expressing a fixed random position p¯¯𝑝\overline{p}over¯ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG to the users for a period of N𝑁Nitalic_N time steps. The term T𝑇Titalic_T is a design parameter, with (N−T)𝑁𝑇(N-T)( italic_N - italic_T ) representing a time instant at which opinions have reached a steady-state. After N𝑁Nitalic_N steps, we obtain the users’ rating xNsuperscript𝑥𝑁x^{N}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and compute their CTR for the position p¯¯𝑝\overline{p}over¯ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG based on the last T𝑇Titalic_T time steps. This process is carried out over m𝑚mitalic_m Monte Carlo trials, thus collecting m𝑚mitalic_m training data points. We emphasize that, similarly to what happens in real life with recommender systems asking the users to rate their experiences, for each trial, we only require access to one sample from the user opinion dynamics, xNsuperscript𝑥𝑁x^{N}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The real time opinions in each trial {xk}k=0N−1superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑥𝑘𝑘0𝑁1\{x^{k}\}_{k=0}^{N-1}{ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_N - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are not needed.

5.2 Proof of Lemma 2

The proof follows from [45, Corollary 5.2] with the continuous function β𝛽\betaitalic_β playing the same role as f𝑓fitalic_f in [45].

In order to provide an explicit upper-bound for exsubscript𝑒𝑥e_{x}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT we point out that the neural network makes use of three layers: the injection layer, whose map is represented by u:ℝn+1→ℝn+2:𝑢→superscriptℝ𝑛1superscriptℝ𝑛2u:\mathbb{R}^{n+1}\to\mathbb{R}^{n+2}italic_u : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the intermediate layer whose map is represented by z:ℝn+2→ℝn+2:𝑧→superscriptℝ𝑛2superscriptℝ𝑛2z:\mathbb{R}^{n+2}\to\mathbb{R}^{n+2}italic_z : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and the output layer, whose map is represented by v:ℝn+2→ℝ:𝑣→superscriptℝ𝑛2ℝv:\mathbb{R}^{n+2}\to\mathbb{R}italic_v : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n + 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R, with v⁢(z)=v⊤⁢z+v0𝑣𝑧superscript𝑣top𝑧subscript𝑣0v(z)=v^{\top}z+v_{0}italic_v ( italic_z ) = italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_z + italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Given that the input and output layers are linear maps, we can directly make use of [46, Theorem 7] to state the following upper-bound ∀i∈[n]for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑛\forall i\in[n]∀ italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ]:

5.3 Proof of Lemma 3.2

Before making use of [45, Corollary 5.2] to prove the upper-bound on eysubscript𝑒𝑦e_{y}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, it is to be noted that the arguments of g𝑔gitalic_g and g^^𝑔\hat{g}over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG, in the definition of eysubscript𝑒𝑦e_{y}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, are different. Thus, we re-write eysubscript𝑒𝑦e_{y}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as ey=g^⁢(p,x^)−g⁢(p,x^)+g⁢(p,x^)−g⁢(p,h⁢(p,d))subscript𝑒𝑦^𝑔𝑝^𝑥𝑔𝑝^𝑥𝑔𝑝^𝑥𝑔𝑝ℎ𝑝𝑑e_{y}=\hat{g}(p,\hat{x})-g(p,\hat{x})+g(p,\hat{x})-g(p,h(p,d))italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ( italic_p , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) - italic_g ( italic_p , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) + italic_g ( italic_p , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) - italic_g ( italic_p , italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) ) and note the following:

∥ey∥delimited-∥∥subscript𝑒𝑦\displaystyle\lVert e_{y}\rVert∥ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ≤(a)⁢∥g^⁢(p,x^)−g⁢(p,x^)∥+∥g⁢(p,h⁢(p,d)+ex)−g⁢(p,h⁢(p,d))∥𝑎delimited-∥∥^𝑔𝑝^𝑥𝑔𝑝^𝑥delimited-∥∥𝑔𝑝ℎ𝑝𝑑subscript𝑒𝑥𝑔𝑝ℎ𝑝𝑑\displaystyle\underset{(a)}{\leq}\lVert\hat{g}(p,\hat{x})-{g}(p,\hat{x})\rVert% +\lVert g(p,h(p,d)+e_{x})-g(p,h(p,d))\rVertstart_UNDERACCENT ( italic_a ) end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG ≤ end_ARG ∥ over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ( italic_p , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) - italic_g ( italic_p , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) ∥ + ∥ italic_g ( italic_p , italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_g ( italic_p , italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) ) ∥
≤(b)⁢∥g^⁢(p,x^)−g⁢(p,x^)∥+∥∇xg⊤⁢(p,h⁢(p,d))⁢ex∥+αy𝑏delimited-∥∥^𝑔𝑝^𝑥𝑔𝑝^𝑥delimited-∥∥subscript∇𝑥superscript𝑔top𝑝ℎ𝑝𝑑subscript𝑒𝑥subscript𝛼𝑦\displaystyle\underset{(b)}{\leq}\lVert\hat{g}(p,\hat{x})-{g}(p,\hat{x})\rVert% +\lVert\nabla_{x}g^{\top}(p,h(p,d))e_{x}\rVert+\alpha_{y}start_UNDERACCENT ( italic_b ) end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG ≤ end_ARG ∥ over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ( italic_p , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) - italic_g ( italic_p , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) ∥ + ∥ ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p , italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) ) italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ + italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT
≤(c)⁢∥g^⁢(p,x^)−g⁢(p,x^)∥+Mx⁢ϵx+αy.𝑐delimited-∥∥^𝑔𝑝^𝑥𝑔𝑝^𝑥subscript𝑀𝑥subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑥subscript𝛼𝑦\displaystyle\underset{(c)}{\leq}\lVert\hat{g}(p,\hat{x})-{g}(p,\hat{x})\rVert% +M_{x}\epsilon_{x}+\alpha_{y}.start_UNDERACCENT ( italic_c ) end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG ≤ end_ARG ∥ over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ( italic_p , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) - italic_g ( italic_p , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) ∥ + italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

In (a)𝑎(a)( italic_a ), we make use of the identity x^=h⁢(p,d)+ex^𝑥ℎ𝑝𝑑subscript𝑒𝑥\hat{x}=h(p,d)+e_{x}over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG = italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with the state estimation error exsubscript𝑒𝑥e_{x}italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT defined in Lemma 2. In (b)𝑏(b)( italic_b ), we use the Taylor series expansion on g⁢(p,h⁢(p,d)+ex)𝑔𝑝ℎ𝑝𝑑subscript𝑒𝑥g(p,h(p,d)+e_{x})italic_g ( italic_p , italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) around x𝑥xitalic_x. In addition, the higher-order terms in the expansion of g⁢(p,h⁢(p,d)+ex)𝑔𝑝ℎ𝑝𝑑subscript𝑒𝑥g(p,h(p,d)+e_{x})italic_g ( italic_p , italic_h ( italic_p , italic_d ) + italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) are upper-bounded by the modelling error on the clicking behaviour, i.e. ∥𝒪(g(p,x))∥≤αy\rVert\mathcal{O}(g(p,x))\lVert\leq\alpha_{y}∥ caligraphic_O ( italic_g ( italic_p , italic_x ) ) ∥ ≤ italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. In (c)𝑐(c)( italic_c ), we use Assumption 2, i.e. g⁢(p,x)𝑔𝑝𝑥g(p,x)italic_g ( italic_p , italic_x ) is Mxsubscript𝑀𝑥M_{x}italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-Lipshitz with respect to x𝑥xitalic_x and the fact that the opinion estimation error is upper-bounded with ∥ex∥≤ϵxdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑒𝑥subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑥\lVert e_{x}\rVert\leq\epsilon_{x}∥ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ≤ italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from Lemma 2.

The existence of an upper-bound on ∥g^⁢(p,x^)−g⁢(p,x^)∥delimited-∥∥^𝑔𝑝^𝑥𝑔𝑝^𝑥\lVert\hat{g}(p,\hat{x})-{g}(p,\hat{x})\rVert∥ over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ( italic_p , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) - italic_g ( italic_p , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) ∥ is similar to the one in Lemma 2. Thus, we directly make use of [46, Theorem 7] to state the following upper-bound ∀i∈[n]for-all𝑖delimited-[]𝑛\forall i\in[n]∀ italic_i ∈ [ italic_n ]:

where suppi∈𝒳p,i,xi∈𝒳x,i⁢|gi⁢(pi,xi)−g^i⁢(pi,xi)|formulae-sequencesubscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝒳𝑝𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖subscript𝒳𝑥𝑖supsubscript𝑔𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖subscript^𝑔𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑥𝑖\underset{p_{i}\in\mathcal{X}_{p,i},x_{i}\in\mathcal{X}_{x,i}}{\mathrm{sup}}|g% _{i}(p_{i},x_{i})-\hat{g}_{i}(p_{i},x_{i})|start_UNDERACCENT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ caligraphic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_sup end_ARG | italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - over^ start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | refers to the maximum training error on each user i𝑖iitalic_i, ωgi⁢(γy)subscript𝜔subscript𝑔𝑖subscript𝛾𝑦\omega_{g_{i}}(\gamma_{y})italic_ω start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_γ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) refers to the modulus of continuity of gisubscript𝑔𝑖g_{i}italic_g start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT on 𝒴𝒴\mathcal{Y}caligraphic_Y, w0,isubscript𝑤0𝑖w_{0,i}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT represents the estimated bias weight w0subscript𝑤0w_{0}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from the penultimate layer to the output layer of the neural network for user i𝑖iitalic_i. It is now possible to state the following:

5.4 Hyper-parameter Tuning

In order to tune the process noise covariance Qksuperscript𝑄𝑘Q^{k}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT we rely on heuristics and qualitative observations. Empirical results on the FJ model suggests that the sensitivity matrix is non-negative. This leads to the condition ℓk+wk≥0n2,∀k∈ℕ0formulae-sequencesuperscriptℓ𝑘superscript𝑤𝑘subscript0superscript𝑛2for-all𝑘subscriptℕ0\ell^{k}+w^{k}\geq 0_{n^{2}},\forall k\in\mathbb{N}_{0}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≥ 0 start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∀ italic_k ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in the random walk (10). Therefore, to ensure a non-negative sensitivity, it is required to have the condition ∥wk∥∞≤min⁢{ℓk}subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝑤𝑘minsuperscriptℓ𝑘\lVert w^{k}\rVert_{\infty}\leq\mathrm{min}\{\ell^{k}\}∥ italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ roman_min { roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }. This condition is satisfied by choosing an M𝑀Mitalic_M large enough such that

σqk=mini:ℓ^ik≠0⁢ℓ^ik/M.superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑞𝑘:𝑖superscriptsubscript^ℓ𝑖𝑘0minsuperscriptsubscript^ℓ𝑖𝑘𝑀\sigma_{q}^{k}=\underset{i:\hat{\ell}_{i}^{k}\neq 0}{\mathrm{min}}\hat{\ell}_{% i}^{k}/M.italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_q end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = start_UNDERACCENT italic_i : over^ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≠ 0 end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_min end_ARG over^ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_M . (21)

Here, M𝑀Mitalic_M is a tuning parameter, to be selected ad hoc. Note in fact, that setting M𝑀Mitalic_M arbitrarily large, the bound ∥wk∥∞≤min⁢{ℓk}subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝑤𝑘minsuperscriptℓ𝑘\lVert w^{k}\rVert_{\infty}\leq\mathrm{min}\{\ell^{k}\}∥ italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ roman_min { roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } becomes looser, but this gives more trust in the process model, resulting in poor learning performances in the posterior estimates.

The measurement noise v𝑣vitalic_v, is tuned by maximizing the measurement likelihood as in [47, Section 3D]. To this end, we solve the following optimization problem online:

(σrk)2=arg(σr)2⁢max⁢P⁢(Δ⁢xssk+1,τi+1|Δ⁢p~k,τi)superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝜎𝑟𝑘2superscriptsubscript𝜎𝑟2argmax𝑃conditionalΔsuperscriptsubscript𝑥ss𝑘1subscript𝜏𝑖1Δsuperscript~𝑝𝑘subscript𝜏𝑖\displaystyle(\sigma_{r}^{k})^{2}=\underset{(\sigma_{r})^{2}}{\mathrm{arg}}{% \mathrm{max}}\ P\Big{(}\Delta{x}_{\rm ss}^{k+1,\tau_{i}+1}\ |\ \Delta\tilde{p}% ^{k,\tau_{i}}\Big{)}( italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = start_UNDERACCENT ( italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_UNDERACCENT start_ARG roman_arg end_ARG roman_max italic_P ( roman_Δ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ss end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | roman_Δ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) (22)

The intuition behind (22) is to find the noise characteristics of v𝑣vitalic_v that best represent the measurement model in (11) using the input Δ⁢pΔ𝑝\Delta proman_Δ italic_p and output Δ⁢xΔ𝑥\Delta{x}roman_Δ italic_x information. Note that, since the true measurements Δ⁢xΔ𝑥\Delta xroman_Δ italic_x are unavailable, they are replaced with Δ⁢x^Δ^𝑥\Delta\hat{x}roman_Δ over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG.

5.5 Proof of Lemma 3.6

Due to Assumption 2 and Lemma 1, for any p,x1,x2∈ℝn𝑝subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2superscriptℝ𝑛p,x_{1},x_{2}\in\mathbb{R}^{n}italic_p , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT it holds that

φctr⁢(p,x1)−φctr⁢(p,x2)−(∇xφctr)⊤⁢(p,x2)⁢(x1−x2)≤12⁢Lx⁢∥x1−x2∥2.superscript𝜑ctr𝑝subscript𝑥1superscript𝜑ctr𝑝subscript𝑥2superscriptsubscript∇𝑥superscript𝜑ctrtop𝑝subscript𝑥2subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥212subscript𝐿𝑥superscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥22\varphi^{\mathrm{ctr}}(p,x_{1})-\varphi^{\mathrm{ctr}}(p,x_{2})-(\nabla_{x}% \varphi^{\mathrm{ctr}})^{\top}(p,x_{2})(x_{1}-x_{2})\leq\frac{1}{2}L_{x}\lVert x% _{1}-x_{2}\rVert^{2}.italic_φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - ( ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

In the above equation, we replace x1,x2subscript𝑥1subscript𝑥2x_{1},x_{2}italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with x+μ⁢ei𝑥𝜇subscript𝑒𝑖x+\mu e_{i}italic_x + italic_μ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and x𝑥xitalic_x, respectively, so that

φctr⁢(p,x+μ⁢ei)−φctr⁢(p,x)−μ⁢(∇xφctr)⊤⁢(p,x)⁢ei≤12⁢Lx⁢μ2.superscript𝜑ctr𝑝𝑥𝜇subscript𝑒𝑖superscript𝜑ctr𝑝𝑥𝜇superscriptsubscript∇𝑥superscript𝜑ctrtop𝑝𝑥subscript𝑒𝑖12subscript𝐿𝑥superscript𝜇2\varphi^{\mathrm{ctr}}(p,x+\mu e_{i})-\varphi^{\mathrm{ctr}}(p,x)-\mu(\nabla_{% x}\varphi^{\mathrm{ctr}})^{\top}(p,x)e_{i}\leq\frac{1}{2}L_{x}\mu^{2}.italic_φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p , italic_x + italic_μ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p , italic_x ) - italic_μ ( ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_p , italic_x ) italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . (23)

Using these definitions in (23), we obtain:

We now write

|(∇xφ^ctr)i⁢(p,x^)−(∇xφctr)i⁢(p,x)|≤12⁢Lx⁢μ+2⁢n⁢ϵgμ,subscriptsubscript∇𝑥superscript^𝜑ctr𝑖𝑝^𝑥subscriptsubscript∇𝑥superscript𝜑ctr𝑖𝑝𝑥12subscript𝐿𝑥𝜇2𝑛subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑔𝜇\Big{|}\Big{(}\nabla_{x}\hat{\varphi}^{\mathrm{ctr}}\Big{)}_{i}(p,\hat{x})-% \Big{(}\nabla_{x}{\varphi}^{\mathrm{ctr}}\Big{)}_{i}(p,x)\Big{|}\leq\frac{1}{2% }L_{x}\mu+2\frac{\sqrt{n}\epsilon_{g}}{\mu},| ( ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_φ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p , over^ start_ARG italic_x end_ARG ) - ( ∇ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_φ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_ctr end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_p , italic_x ) | ≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_μ + 2 divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_μ end_ARG ,

from which (14) follows. Analogous reasoning is followed for the gradient estimation error with respect to p𝑝pitalic_p. To obtain the tight upper-bound, we use first-order optimality conditions with respect to μ𝜇\muitalic_μ on the term 12⁢Lx⁢μ+2⁢n⁢ϵgμ12subscript𝐿𝑥𝜇2𝑛subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑔𝜇\frac{1}{2}L_{x}\mu+2\frac{\sqrt{n}\epsilon_{g}}{\mu}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_μ + 2 divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_μ end_ARG, thus obtaining μ∗=2⁢n1/4⁢ϵg/Lxsuperscript𝜇2superscript𝑛14subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑔subscript𝐿𝑥\mu^{*}=2n^{1/4}\sqrt{\epsilon_{g}/L_{x}}italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 2 italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT square-root start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG. Since the second-order derivative of the term 12⁢Lx⁢μ+2⁢n⁢ϵgμ12subscript𝐿𝑥𝜇2𝑛subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑔𝜇\frac{1}{2}L_{x}\mu+2\frac{\sqrt{n}\epsilon_{g}}{\mu}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_μ + 2 divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_n end_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_g end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_μ end_ARG is strictly positive, μ∗superscript𝜇\mu^{*}italic_μ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the smoothing parameter that provides the lowest upper-bound on the gradient estimation error.

5.6 Proof of Theorem 3.8

The Kalman filter is uniformly asymptotically stable provided the pairs (In2,Qk),(In2,Δ⁢p~k,τi)subscript𝐼superscript𝑛2superscript𝑄𝑘subscript𝐼superscript𝑛2Δsuperscript~𝑝𝑘subscript𝜏𝑖(I_{n^{2}},\sqrt{Q^{k}}),(I_{n^{2}},\Delta\tilde{p}^{k,\tau_{i}})( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , square-root start_ARG italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) , ( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Δ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) are uniformly completely controllable and observable, respectively [48, Theorem 7.4]. By design (see Appendix 5.4), the process noise covariance Qksuperscript𝑄𝑘Q^{k}italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is positive definite ∀k∈ℕ0for-all𝑘subscriptℕ0\forall k\in\mathbb{N}_{0}∀ italic_k ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, from which the matrix pair (In2,Qk)subscript𝐼superscript𝑛2superscript𝑄𝑘(I_{n^{2}},\sqrt{Q^{k}})( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , square-root start_ARG italic_Q start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) is uniformly completely controllable.

To prove observability of (In2,Δ⁢p~k,τi)subscript𝐼superscript𝑛2Δsuperscript~𝑝𝑘subscript𝜏𝑖(I_{n^{2}},\Delta\tilde{p}^{k,\tau_{i}})( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Δ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ), we consider the following observability Gramian matrix [48, Chapter 7.5]:

WO⁢(l1,l2):=∑l=l1l2(Δ⁢p~τi−l+1,τi−l)⊤⁢(Rτi−l+1)−1⁢(Δ⁢p~τi−l+1,τi−l).assignsubscript𝑊𝑂subscript𝑙1subscript𝑙2superscriptsubscript𝑙subscript𝑙1subscript𝑙2superscriptΔsuperscript~𝑝subscript𝜏𝑖𝑙1subscript𝜏𝑖𝑙topsuperscriptsuperscript𝑅subscript𝜏𝑖𝑙11Δsuperscript~𝑝subscript𝜏𝑖𝑙1subscript𝜏𝑖𝑙W_{O}(l_{1},l_{2}):=\sum_{l=l_{1}}^{l_{2}}(\Delta\tilde{p}^{\tau_{i-l+1},\tau_% {i-l}})^{\top}(R^{\tau_{i-l+1}})^{-1}(\Delta\tilde{p}^{\tau_{i-l+1},\tau_{i-l}% }).italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_O end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) := ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_Δ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_Δ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) . (25)

The matrix pair (In2,Δ⁢p~k,τi)subscript𝐼superscript𝑛2Δsuperscript~𝑝𝑘subscript𝜏𝑖(I_{n^{2}},\Delta\tilde{p}^{k,\tau_{i}})( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Δ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is said to be uniformly completely observable if ∃α,β>0𝛼𝛽0\exists\ \alpha,\beta>0∃ italic_α , italic_β > 0 and an N∈ℕ0:0<α⁢In2≤WO⁢(k−N,k)≤β⁢In2:𝑁subscriptℕ00𝛼subscript𝐼superscript𝑛2subscript𝑊𝑂𝑘𝑁𝑘𝛽subscript𝐼superscript𝑛2N\in\mathbb{N}_{0}:0<\alpha I_{n^{2}}\leq W_{O}(k-N,k)\leq\beta I_{n^{2}}italic_N ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : 0 < italic_α italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_O end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_k - italic_N , italic_k ) ≤ italic_β italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Since Δ⁢p~t1,t2:=Δ⁢pt1,t2⊗InassignΔsuperscript~𝑝subscript𝑡1subscript𝑡2tensor-productΔsuperscript𝑝subscript𝑡1subscript𝑡2subscript𝐼𝑛\Delta\tilde{p}^{t_{1},t_{2}}:=\Delta p^{t_{1},t_{2}}\otimes I_{n}roman_Δ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := roman_Δ italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊗ italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we write WO⁢(l1,l2)=∑l=l1l2(Δ⁢pτi−l+1,τi−l)⁢(Δ⁢pτi−l+1,τi−l)⊤⊗(Rτi−l+1)−1subscript𝑊𝑂subscript𝑙1subscript𝑙2superscriptsubscript𝑙subscript𝑙1subscript𝑙2tensor-productΔsuperscript𝑝subscript𝜏𝑖𝑙1subscript𝜏𝑖𝑙superscriptΔsuperscript𝑝subscript𝜏𝑖𝑙1subscript𝜏𝑖𝑙topsuperscriptsuperscript𝑅subscript𝜏𝑖𝑙11W_{O}(l_{1},l_{2})=\sum_{l=l_{1}}^{l_{2}}(\Delta{p}^{\tau_{i-l+1},\tau_{i-l}})% (\Delta{p}^{\tau_{i-l+1},\tau_{i-l}})^{\top}\otimes(R^{\tau_{i-l+1}})^{-1}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_O end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( roman_Δ italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊗ ( italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. With an appropriate choice of M𝑀Mitalic_M in (21), we have α1⁢In≤Rk≤α2⁢In,∀k∈ℕ0formulae-sequencesubscript𝛼1subscript𝐼𝑛superscript𝑅𝑘subscript𝛼2subscript𝐼𝑛for-all𝑘subscriptℕ0\alpha_{1}I_{n}\leq R^{k}\leq\alpha_{2}I_{n},\forall k\in\mathbb{N}_{0}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∀ italic_k ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, with α1>0subscript𝛼10\alpha_{1}>0italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 and α2<∞subscript𝛼2\alpha_{2}<\inftyitalic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < ∞, leading to 1α2≤(Rτi−l+1)−1≤1α11subscript𝛼2superscriptsuperscript𝑅subscript𝜏𝑖𝑙111subscript𝛼1\frac{1}{\alpha_{2}}\leq(R^{\tau_{i-l+1}})^{-1}\leq\frac{1}{\alpha_{1}}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ≤ ( italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i - italic_l + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG. Moreover, the persistency of excitation assumption (see Assumption 5) on the inputs Δ⁢pΔ𝑝\Delta proman_Δ italic_p enable us to state that ∃S∈ℕ0:β1⁢In≤∑l=k−Sk(Δ⁢pτi−l+1,τi−l)⁢(Δ⁢pτi−l+1,τi−l)⊤≤β2⁢In:𝑆subscriptℕ0subscript𝛽1subscript𝐼𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑙𝑘𝑆𝑘Δsuperscript𝑝subscript𝜏𝑖𝑙1subscript𝜏𝑖𝑙superscriptΔsuperscript𝑝subscript𝜏𝑖𝑙1subscript𝜏𝑖𝑙topsubscript𝛽2subscript𝐼𝑛\exists\ S\in\mathbb{N}_{0}:\beta_{1}I_{n}\leq\sum_{l=k-S}^{k}(\Delta{p}^{\tau% _{i-l+1},\tau_{i-l}})(\Delta{p}^{\tau_{i-l+1},\tau_{i-l}})^{\top}\leq\beta_{2}% I_{n}∃ italic_S ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l = italic_k - Thus, the matrix pair (In2,Δ⁢p~k,τi)subscript𝐼superscript𝑛2Δsuperscript~𝑝𝑘subscript𝜏𝑖(I_{n^{2}},\Delta\tilde{p}^{k,\tau_{i}})( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_Δ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) is uniformly completely observable and it is now possible to state that the Kalman filter is uniformly asymptotically stable.

We can now derive an explicit analytical expression for the upper-bound on the bias ∥𝔼⁢[ek]∥delimited-∥∥𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑒𝑘\lVert\mathbb{E}[e^{k}]\rVert∥ blackboard_E [ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ∥ and the variance 𝔼⁢[∥ek∥2]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝑒𝑘2\mathbb{E}[\lVert e^{k}\rVert^{2}]blackboard_E [ ∥ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ]. By making use of (10) and (3.2.1) on ℓksuperscriptℓ𝑘\ell^{k}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ℓ^ksuperscript^ℓ𝑘\hat{\ell}^{k}over^ start_ARG roman_ℓ end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, by adding and subtracting Δ⁢xssk+1,τi+1Δsuperscriptsubscript𝑥ss𝑘1subscript𝜏𝑖1\Delta x_{\rm ss}^{k+1,\tau_{i}+1}roman_Δ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ss end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPTand by making use of (10) and (11) on Δ⁢xssk+1,τi+1Δsuperscriptsubscript𝑥ss𝑘1subscript𝜏𝑖1\Delta x_{\rm ss}^{k+1,\tau_{i}+1}roman_Δ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ss end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k + 1 , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, one gets

eksuperscript𝑒𝑘\displaystyle e^{k}italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT =(In2−ζk⁢Kk−1⁢Δ⁢p~k,τi)⁢(ek−1+wk−1)−ζk⁢Kk−1⁢vkabsentsubscript𝐼superscript𝑛2superscript𝜁𝑘superscript𝐾𝑘1Δsuperscript~𝑝𝑘subscript𝜏𝑖superscript𝑒𝑘1superscript𝑤𝑘1superscript𝜁𝑘superscript𝐾𝑘1superscript𝑣𝑘\displaystyle=\big{(}I_{n^{2}}-\zeta^{k}K^{k-1}\Delta\tilde{p}^{k,\tau_{i}}% \big{)}(e^{k-1}+w^{k-1})-\zeta^{k}K^{k-1}v^{k}= ( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_ζ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Δ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ( italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_ζ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

(26)

(27)

Taking the expectation on both sides of the above equation and using Assumption 4, we have:

𝔼⁢[ek]=(In2−Kk−1⁢Δ⁢p~k,τi)⁢𝔼⁢[eτi]+Kk−1⁢𝔼⁢[Δ⁢exτi+1,k+1].𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑒𝑘subscript𝐼superscript𝑛2superscript𝐾𝑘1Δsuperscript~𝑝𝑘subscript𝜏𝑖𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑒subscript𝜏𝑖superscript𝐾𝑘1𝔼delimited-[]Δsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑥subscript𝜏𝑖1𝑘1\mathbb{E}[e^{k}]=\big{(}I_{n^{2}}-K^{k-1}\Delta\tilde{p}^{k,\tau_{i}}\big{)}% \mathbb{E}[e^{\tau_{i}}]+K^{k-1}\mathbb{E}[\Delta e_{x}^{\tau_{i}+1,k+1}].blackboard_E [ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] = ( italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Δ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) blackboard_E [ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] + italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_E [ roman_Δ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 , italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] . (28)

Since we have already established uniform complete observability, the Kalman filter gain Kksuperscript𝐾𝑘K^{k}italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT settles to a steady-state value Kssubscript𝐾𝑠K_{s}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as k→∞→𝑘k\to\inftyitalic_k → ∞. Thus, we can state that ∃Km:∥Kk∥≤Km,∀k∈ℕ0:subscript𝐾𝑚formulae-sequencedelimited-∥∥superscript𝐾𝑘subscript𝐾𝑚for-all𝑘superscriptℕ0\exists\ K_{m}:\lVert K^{k}\rVert\leq K_{m},\forall\ k\in\mathbb{N}^{0}∃ italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : ∥ italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ ≤ italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∀ italic_k ∈ blackboard_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Further, denoting ψ⁢(τi+1,τi):=In2−Kτi+1−1⁢Δ⁢p~τi+1,τiassign𝜓subscript𝜏𝑖1subscript𝜏𝑖subscript𝐼superscript𝑛2superscript𝐾subscript𝜏𝑖11Δsuperscript~𝑝subscript𝜏𝑖1subscript𝜏𝑖\psi(\tau_{i+1},\tau_{i}):=I_{n^{2}}-K^{\tau_{i+1}-1}\Delta\tilde{p}^{\tau_{i+% 1},\tau_{i}}italic_ψ ( italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) := italic_I start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_K start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Δ over~ start_ARG italic_p end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT as the state transition matrix for the Kalman filter error eksuperscript𝑒𝑘e^{k}italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, uniform asymptotic stability leads to ∥ψ⁢(τi+1,τi)∥≤c1⁢ξc2⁢Tdelimited-∥∥𝜓subscript𝜏𝑖1subscript𝜏𝑖subscript𝑐1superscript𝜉subscript𝑐2𝑇\lVert\psi(\tau_{i+1},\tau_{i})\rVert\leq c_{1}\xi^{c_{2}T}∥ italic_ψ ( italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ∥ ≤ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for some c1,c2>0,ξ∈(0,1):c1ξc2⁢T<1c_{1},c_{2}>0,\xi\in(0,1):c_{1}\xi^{c_{2}T}<1italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0 , italic_ξ ∈ ( 0 , 1 ) : italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT < 1, where τi+1=ksubscript𝜏𝑖1𝑘\tau_{i+1}=kitalic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_k is the new trigger time instant and T𝑇Titalic_T is the time period. Thus, taking the norm on both sides in (28), we have ∥𝔼⁢[eτi+1]∥≤c1⁢ξc2⁢T⁢∥𝔼⁢[eτi]∥+2⁢Km⁢ϵxdelimited-∥∥𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑒subscript𝜏𝑖1subscript𝑐1superscript𝜉subscript𝑐2𝑇delimited-∥∥𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑒subscript𝜏𝑖2subscript𝐾𝑚subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑥\lVert\mathbb{E}[e^{\tau_{i+1}}]\rVert\leq c_{1}\xi^{c_{2}T}\lVert\mathbb{E}[e% ^{\tau_{i}}]\rVert+2K_{m}\epsilon_{x}∥ blackboard_E [ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ∥ ≤ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ blackboard_E [ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ∥ + 2 italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where we note that sup⁢∥𝔼⁢[Δ⁢exτi+1,k+1]∥≤𝔼⁢[∥Δ⁢exτi+1,k+1∥]≤2⁢ϵxsupdelimited-∥∥𝔼delimited-[]Δsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑥subscript𝜏𝑖1𝑘1𝔼delimited-[]delimited-∥∥Δsuperscriptsubscript𝑒𝑥subscript𝜏𝑖1𝑘12subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑥\mathrm{sup}\ \lVert\mathbb{E}[\Delta e_{x}^{\tau_{i}+1,k+1}]\rVert\leq\mathbb% {E}[\lVert\Delta e_{x}^{\tau_{i}+1,k+1}\rVert]\leq 2\epsilon_{x}roman_sup ∥ blackboard_E [ roman_Δ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 , italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ∥ ≤ blackboard_E [ ∥ roman_Δ italic_e start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 , italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ ] ≤ 2 italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from Lemma 2. Hence, we derive the bias equation

∥𝔼⁢[eτi+1]∥≤(c1⁢ξc2⁢T)|𝒯|⁢∥𝔼⁢[e0]∥+2⁢Km⁢ϵx⁢1−(c1⁢ξc2⁢T)|𝒯|1−c1⁢ξc2⁢T,delimited-∥∥𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑒subscript𝜏𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑐1superscript𝜉subscript𝑐2𝑇𝒯delimited-∥∥𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑒02subscript𝐾𝑚subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑥1superscriptsubscript𝑐1superscript𝜉subscript𝑐2𝑇𝒯1subscript𝑐1superscript𝜉subscript𝑐2𝑇\lVert\mathbb{E}[e^{\tau_{i+1}}]\rVert\leq\big{(}c_{1}\xi^{c_{2}T}\big{)}^{|% \mathcal{T}|}\lVert\mathbb{E}[e^{0}]\rVert+2K_{m}\epsilon_{x}\frac{1-(c_{1}\xi% ^{c_{2}T})^{|\mathcal{T}|}}{1-c_{1}\xi^{c_{2}T}},∥ blackboard_E [ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ∥ ≤ ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | caligraphic_T | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ blackboard_E [ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ∥ + 2 italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 - ( italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | caligraphic_T | end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ,

where, 𝒯:={τ0,τ1,…,τi}assign𝒯subscript𝜏0subscript𝜏1…subscript𝜏𝑖\mathcal{T}:=\{\tau_{0},\tau_{1},\dots,\tau_{i}\}caligraphic_T := { italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } is the set of all trigger time instances upto τisubscript𝜏𝑖\tau_{i}italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Thus, we have the asymptotic result on the bias lim|𝒯|→∞𝔼⁢[eτi]≤2⁢Km⁢ϵx/(1−c1⁢ξc2⁢T)subscript→𝒯𝔼delimited-[]superscript𝑒subscript𝜏𝑖2subscript𝐾𝑚subscriptitalic-ϵ𝑥1subscript𝑐1superscript𝜉subscript𝑐2𝑇\lim_{|\mathcal{T}|\to\infty}\mathbb{E}[e^{\tau_{i}}]\leq 2K_{m}\epsilon_{x}/(% 1-c_{1}\xi^{c_{2}T})roman_lim start_POSTSUBSCRIPT | caligraphic_T | → ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_E [ italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ] ≤ 2 italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / ( 1 - italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).
